pages.subdeck: Build up ... Asda garage in Waterlooville, Hants
pages.headline: No10: Fill up quick before fuel strike
pages.teaser: MOTORISTS should fill up with petrol fast before tanker strike closes garages, No10 says
pages.byline: By TOM NEWTON DUNN, Political Editor, and GRAEME WILSON
pages.articlebody:
MOTORISTS should fill up their petrol tanks fast before a tanker strike closes garages, No10 said yesterday.

Downing Street issued the stark warning in contradiction to the AA, who yesterday urged drivers NOT to panic buy.

As the potential crisis escalates, The Sun can reveal that PM David Cameron will this afternoon chair a meeting of the Government's emergency committee COBRA.

He will personally take charge of planning to stop the dispute closing down Britain.

And with the threat of an Easter walkout, the conciliation service Acas has invited unions and oil companies to hold talks in a bid to stop it happening.

Long queues were already forming at some petrol stations yesterday, and some ran out. Drivers were spotted lining up in Waterlooville, Hants; Slough, Berks and Heathrow Airport.

The PM's official spokeswoman said: "It is important that people look at their contingency plans, particularly businesses. Because should there be a dispute  which we want to avoid  then disruption would be inevitable." Asked whether her words were irresponsible, she said: "Currently there are no problems with fuel supplies".

Labour branded the Government's advice to fill up "the height of irresponsibility" if it leads to a rush on reserves and petrol stations run dry. But it emerged last night the risky warning was a tactic to heap pressure on Unite.

Ministers were told that if every motorist in the country fills up their tank, garages will be restocked in time to thwart any strike action.

The Unite union's 2,000 fuel tanker drivers voted to walk out indefinitely with just seven days' notice in a row about terms and conditions and safety standards. The strike could come as early as Easter.

The looming stoppage was top of the agenda yesterday at a meeting of the National Security Council.

The Sun has been campaigning to freeze duty on petrol.

t.newtondunn@the-sun.co.uk



999 man 'ignored'

FIVE desperate calls were made to striking 999 workers before an ambulance was sent to help a dying pensioner, it was revealed yesterday.

The 83-year-old man died from a heart attack as he was finally being taken to a London hospital during November's public sector pensions walkout.

image.caption: Build up ... Asda garage in Waterlooville, Hants

pages.subdeck: Sun campaign ... for VAT U-turn
pages.headline: Let them eat cold pasty
pages.teaser: GEORGE Osborne says poor people can avoid hot food VAT hike by buying COLD pasties
pages.byline: By TOM NEWTON DUNN, Political Editor, and STEVE HAWKES, Business Editor
pages.articlebody:
GEORGE Osborne was branded "heartless" yesterday for saying hard-pressed Brits could avoid his VAT hike on hot food by buying COLD pasties.

He was BRANDED a modern-day Marie Antoinette for suggesting broke Brits could dodge the 20 per cent price hike by buying cold pasties, pies and sausage rolls.

And his Treasury was ACCUSED of being "insensitive" to hardship by popular bakery shop chain Greggs.

The Chancellor slapped on the tax in his Budget last week. But yesterday he clashed with Labour MP John Mann during a Treasury Committee hearing on his annual economic blueprint.

Pressed on whether the "pasty tax" was fair, Mr Osborne said: "If it's cold when you buy it, it will not be VAT-able." Mr Mann also asked: "When was the last time you bought a pasty in Greggs?" The Chancellor replied: "I can't remember."

The Labour MP told The Sun later: "It just shows how out of touch Osborne is.

"It's obvious he has never been in Greggs so he'll have no idea on the impact this measure will have. Let them eat cold pasties  how heartless. It sounds just like Marie Antoinette."

The Sun has launched a "Who VAT All the Pies" campaign to demand the Chancellor U-turn before the tax starts on October 1. Hot takeaway food from bakery shops is a staple of ordinary Brits.

Mr Osborne tried to justify his VAT move by saying he was simply imposing a law passed in 1984 decreeing tax should be paid on such grub.

He added: "Since then there has been a lot of legal action to try to get round that. If you buy your pasty in a fish and chip shop, it almost certainly has VAT on it."

But the Chancellor was hit by a Coalition revolt as three West Country Lib Dem MPs signed a Commons motion calling for the "humble Cornish pasty" to be exempt. Greggs were left crestfallen after meeting Treasury minister David Gauke, who insisted there would be no U-turn.

The chain's chief Ken McMeikan said: "He is insensitive to how hard life is without putting up the price of food."

Mr McMeikan produced a letter from ex-Chancellor Nigel Lawson, who appeared to contradict Mr Osborne's assertion by declaring in 1984 that VAT should NOT apply to freshly-baked savouries.

The boss said: "The point is that these are freshly-baked products that are cooling down, not remaining heated. They just don't get it."

Mr Osborne did offer one ray of hope for taxpayers by telling MPs he was bringing in a new form of Treasury accounting. Under the system, called Dynamic Scoring, taxes that fail to raise as much revenue as expected will be considered for the chop.

t.newtondunn@the-sun.co.uk



Crumb off it

THE Chancellor's cold pasty remark echoes the legendary "Let them eat cake" jibe attributed to French queen Marie Antoinette.

The lavishly spoiled wife of King Louis XVI is said to have uttered it after being told peasants had no bread. She was executed by guillotine along with the king in 1793 during the French Revolution.

image.caption: Sun campaign ... for VAT U-turn

article.caption: Pasty tax gets a pasting
So nasty to hit pasties
We have never really all been 'in it together'. And we're less 'all in it together' now than ever

pages.subdeck: Humiliation ... X Factor judge Tulisa
pages.headline: It's all Tu much
pages.teaser: SINGER and X Factor judge paranoid people are laughing about her behind her back
pages.articlebody:
TULISA cut short her first big night out since her sex tape scandal after being rubbed up the wrong way by guests at a party.

The X Factor judge had an early night after getting paranoid about people talking behind her back at a bash following a Drake gig.

She was also a bit red-faced at the start of the rapper's show at London's O2 Arena when she bumped into the JLS boys in her private box.

A source said: "Tulisa was really looking forward to escaping all the embarrassment of the past week with a good night out.

"She knew the JLS boys were going to be there but felt really awkward when she walked in because she presumed the lads had seen the tape.

"She said a quiet 'Hello' to them  but then went straight out the back door, let out a big squeal and took a deep breath before going back in to face them.

"Tulisa and her pals hardly spoke to JLS throughout the gig. It was a really uncomfortable atmosphere because she is so embarrassed about the tape."

But the former N-Dubz singer's night got worse when she went backstage to see Drake and Florence Welch.

The Canadian rapper took a shine to Tulisa and called her the "Princess of the UK".

But she didn't stick around after sensing people were making comments behind her back about the sex tape. She headed home for an early night.

Drake had better be careful asking for her number in future. Tulisa won't be too happy having a mobile phone shoved in her face these days.

image.caption: Humiliation ... X Factor judge Tulisa

article.caption: Tulisa ex comes out of hiding for High Court date in London
Tu's company

pages.subdeck: BRIGHT SPARKS ... Rob hails his Estadio Da Luz heroes
pages.headline: Estadio Da Bluz
pages.teaser: ROBERTO DI MATTEO hailed his bright sparks after Kalou's goal sealed stunning victory
pages.articlebody:
CHELSEA put one foot in the Champions League semi-finals with a stunning victory.

Salomon Kalou's 75th-minute clincher here turned the Estadio Da Luz into the Estadio Da Bluz.

Kalou struck from six yards after a Fernando Torres set-up.

It delighted caretaker-boss Roberto Di Matteo, who admitted he had gambled on the Ivory Coast star and several other players as the Blues took a massive stride towards a likely semi date with Lionel Messi and Barcelona.

Di Matteo said: "Salomon has come into the team after a long spell out. He got the goal and had a great game. Sometimes in life you have to take a little risk and, with all the games we are playing, it was important to select a team that had the energy for a high-tempo game like this.

"I am trying to involve all the players in the squad, as we are going to need them before the end of this season.

"Paulo Ferreira hadn't played for a while but he was outstanding too and you will see others who played less in the past have more of a role in future.

"One of the reasons behind my putting in players like Raul Meireles, Ferreira, David Luiz and Ramires was because they all know Benfica well and the atmosphere they would be facing.

"But the whole squad was outstanding. It's a terrific result for us and an excellent performance.

"We couldn't have hoped for better. We went close on a number of occasions, kept a clean sheet and I always fancied us to score a goal.

"Even so, we've not gone through yet."

Di Matteo left the likes of Frank Lampard, Didier Drogba and Michael Essien on the bench following last weekend's 0-0 draw with Tottenham.

Yet the visitors were still easily good enough to keep at bay a side that twice held Manchester United in the group stage.

Delighted Kalou, so often an unsung sub, said: "The manager gave me the chance to play and I am happy to give everything to help my team."

Team-mate John Obi Mikel stated: "We put in a hard shift, hoped we would get a chance  and we did."

It was not all good news for Chelsea, with goalkeeping coach Christophe Lochillon sent to the stands late on after a row with the fourth official.

pages.subdeck: Thusha ... life in a wheelchair
pages.headline: Help raise £30k for shot Thusha
pages.teaser: Shot Thusha: I fear being harmed again
pages.articlebody:
THE little girl left paralysed after being shot by gang-feud hoodies said yesterday: "I worry that someone will try and hurt me again."

Six-year-old Thusha Kamaleswaran said she misses being able to dance, her friends, her family and going to school.

Speaking for the first time while sat beside her mother Sharmila, 35, she went on: "I cannot move. I wanted to be a dancer.

"I wanted to learn to dance properly. Now I am stuck in the hospital in a wheelchair learning to wheel myself around.

"I am scared to get into the car because of the strangers all around us. I worry someone will try to hurt me again."

Thusha was only five when she was shot as three gangsters hunted down a rival hiding in her uncle's store in Stockwell, South London, last March.

Her uncle, Mahadavan, 33, said: "Thusha talks about it all the time. She says, 'When I went to my uncle's shop my legs were broken. Bad men did it'."

The bullet went into her chest and left her unable to move her legs. Britain's youngest gangland victim, she is due to be released from hospital next week and will spend the rest of her life in a wheelchair.

She said she doesn't like people constantly talking about what happened to her. Now her dreams of being a dancer are over, all she has left is to watch old footage of her performing.

Thusha was a natural, picking up a complex ten-minute Indian routine in just a fortnight before the gun attack.

The three thugs were convicted at the Old Bailey on Monday of attempted murder of the rival and GBH with intent on Thusha.

Nathaniel Grant, 21, Kazeem Kolawole, 19, and Anthony McCalla, 20, will be sentenced in April. Harrowing CCTV footage released by cops after the court case showed Thusha dancing, but seconds later floored by the .22 bullet.

a.crick@the-sun.co.uk



Cops: Raise £30k



By Anthony France

BIG-hearted cops who investigated the shooting of Thusha have launched an appeal to raise at least £30,000 for her.

Fifteen detectives and support staff are to kick off the fund-raising by climbing the three highest peaks in the UK.

They want The Sun's army of generous readers to help raise the rest of the cash towards vital equipment for the paralysed six-year-old. Thusha  due to leave hospital next week  will spend the rest of her days in a wheelchair.

She will need round-the-clock care and never be independent. But cops from the Met's Trident Gang Command are determined to make her life better. Det Con Richard Williamson, 37, said: "Her condition will never improve but your readers can make it a lot more bearable."

a.france@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Thusha ... life in a wheelchair

article.caption: Mum weeps at CCTV of 5yr-old girl's shooting
Girl, 5, was shot 'while playing in shop'

pages.subdeck: Crown jewel ... toast rack
pages.headline: Toast whack
pages.teaser: A SILVER toast rack fit for a king is on sale at Kensington Palace  for £1,000
pages.articlebody:
A SILVER toast rack fit for a king is on sale at Kensington Palace  for £1,000.

The holder is among replica royal items being flogged at the newly-refurbished residence.

Visitors can make up a breakfast set with an £800 silver egg cup, a silver butter knife for £250, gold plated salt and pepper shakers for £750 and a napkin holder for £500.

A source at the palace in central London said: "One thousand pounds is a lot to spend on a toast rack.

"I don't think many of us will be eating our breakfast off that any time soon. But it is a quality product made in the royal style from solid silver with a gold-plated trim.

"Very similar-looking stainless steel toast racks are also for sale. These are very popular and more affordable at £40 each." The 407-year-old palace opened to public this week following a £12million revamp. It is set to become the home of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge  Prince William and wife Kate  next year.

The palace is most recently famous for being the home of William's late mother Princess Diana, who had her own apartment in one of the wings.

Tickets cost £14.50 for adults, £12 for concessions and children are allowed in free. All the profits from the entrance fee and the gift shop go to Historic Royal Palaces, which is the charity responsible for the upkeep of the five royal palaces.

Kensington Palace receives no Government cash. The two-year £12million refurbishment has been paid for with Lottery funding and support from a number of charitable trusts.

It was officially re-opened by the Queen earlier this month to coincide with her Diamond Jubilee this year.

Some 380,000 people are expected to visit the palace this year.

  • THE extended Bank Holiday for the Queen's Diamond Jubilee celebrations in June will HIT the economy by reducing output, Bank of England governor Sir Mervyn King said yesterday.

    a.peake@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Crown jewel ... toast rack

article.caption: Stick 'em up!
Heir, that face looks familiar

pages.subdeck: Transformation ... Richard Lee Norris in 1993, left, after the accident and following surgery
pages.headline: New face for man disfigured by gun
pages.teaser: RICHARD Lee Norris needed 36-hour surgery after his face was accidentally blasted off
pages.articlebody:
THIS is the amazing transformation of a man who was given a new face 15 years after blasting off his old one with a gun.

Richard Lee Norris, 37, lived as a virtual recluse since the accident  hiding his face with a mask and shopping after dark.

Doctors have ended his torment by giving him a new face, nose, teeth and jaw in a 36-hour operation.

Richard, from Hillsville, Virginia, US, had the procedure last week and is already beginning to feel his face, shave and brush his teeth.

He has also regained his sense of smell.

Lead surgeon Dr Eduardo Rodriguez, of the University of Maryland Medical Center in Baltimore, said: "It's a surreal experience to look at him. It's hard not to stare.

"Before, people used to stare at Richard because he wore a mask and they wanted to see the deformity. Now, they have another reason to stare at him, and it's really amazing.

"This accidental injury just destroyed everything. The rest of his friends and colleagues went on to start getting married, having children, owning homes. He wants to make up for all of that."

Dr Rodriguez added that Richard does not resemble the donor despite the new face. He said: "It's a combination of two individuals, a true blend."

Before the transplant Norris could see but had no teeth, no nose and only part of his tongue. He was still able to taste but could not smell.

It is the 23rd face transplant since the first carried out seven years ago when a woman mauled by a dog in France was given a new face.

image.caption: Transformation ... Richard Lee Norris in 1993, left, after the accident and following surgery

article.caption: Chimp attack woman's new face

pages.subdeck: Shamed and shackled ... Liam Stacey is led from court
pages.headline: Tweet justice as troll is caged
pages.teaser: STUDENT Liam Stacey jailed for sick racist Twitter tirade over soccer's Fabrice Muamba
pages.articlebody:
STUDENT Liam Stacey was led away sobbing in handcuffs yesterday as he was jailed for a sick racist tirade on Twitter after soccer's Fabrice Muamba almost died on the pitch.

The biology undergraduate, 21, fell into the arms of his mum as he was taken from the dock  his university prospects wrecked by his idiocy.

Boozed-up Stacey tweeted as the Bolton Wanderers star, 23, fought for life after his heart attack at Spurs 11 days ago: "LOL (laugh out loud). F*** Muamba. He's dead!!!"

District Judge John Charles slammed the "vile and abhorrent" posting, which Stacey followed up with frenzied racist abuse when fellow Twitter users  many of them black  objected.

The Swansea University student's mum Hayley, 46, and office worker dad Neale, 49, looked visibly shocked as the venomous messages were read out.

Judge Charles, who was presiding at Swansea Magistrates Court, was unmoved by pleas to not jail their son  who was in the third year of his degree course and about to take finals.

He caged the student for eight weeks, declaring that he had caused "public outrage".

The judge said that when Muamba collapsed, "it was not the football world who was praying for him  everybody was praying for his life".

The star, who was rushed to hospital, is now on the mend.

The student admitted racially-aggravated harassment and disorder. He had earlier trembled as prosecutors argued the case was so serious it should go to a crown court  where he could have been jailed for six months.

Stacey, of Pontypridd, South Wales, had hoped for a career as a forensic scientist but now faces expulsion from university.

The Sun is campaigning against trolls, urging readers to alert internet service providers  and in extreme cases the police.

Jim Brisbane, Chief Crown Prosecutor for Wales, said: "Racist language is inappropriate through any media. We hope this case will serve as a warning."

  • SOCCER fans took to Twitter yesterday to blast Man U fanzine Red Issue for a headline over a picture of prone Muamba saying: "Grief junkies run riot."

    Speech bubbles from the crowd joke: "Is he dead?" and "I've Tweeted my condolences just in case". Outraged supporters branded it a "disgrace".

    Players and fans hail Muamba

    THE fans and players of Bolton and Spurs were reunited last night as the teams replayed their abandoned game 11 days after Fabrice Muamba collapsed.

    Tottenham striker Jermain Defoe was among the stars to warm up in a "Uniting for Fabrice" T-shirt before the White Hart Lane crowd joined the players in a minute's applause.

    The stadium announcer then thanked all supporters for their compassion. Guest of honour at the FA Cup quarter-final  which Spurs won 3-1  was heart doc Andrew Deaner, who ran on to the field to save Muamba.

image.caption: Shamed and shackled ... Liam Stacey is led from court

video.caption: STUDENT Liam Stacey student mocked footballer after collapse

article.caption: Muamba Twitter troll is jailed

pages.subdeck: North Sea gas leak ... Total's Elgin platform (inset, BP's oil platform blazes after 2010 leak)
pages.headline: Blast fear over North Sea leak
pages.teaser: NORTH Sea gas leak could take six months to fix, sparking environmental disaster fears
pages.articlebody:
FEARS a leaking North Sea gas well could explode heightened today when it was revealed there is a flame still BURNING on the rig.

All 238 workers have been evacuated from Total's Elgin platform since it sprang a leak on Sunday.

Experts said if the gas ignited with a naked flame in the rig's flare it could lead to "complete destruction" at the well.

Last night Total attempted to play down the risk saying the wind is blowing the gas plume in the opposite direction to the flare.

A spokesman said it was "left on deliberately" when the platform was evacuated. He added the flame was still alight at 5.30pm last night but had "reduced in size" and was expected "to go out within a few hours".

Meanwhile, exclusion zones are in place to keep ships and planes away. A cloud of gas is visible above the platform, which is 150 miles from Aberdeen, and workers said they saw the sea "bubbling".

A six-mile "sheen" on the sea surface was caused by leaking gas that condensed into liquid.

Energy expert Frederic Hauge said: "This is the well from hell. The problem is out of control.

"They saw the sea bubbling with gas under the platform."

Jake Molloy, of offshore workers union RMT, said: "Total acted very swiftly in getting everyone off but the potential still exists for catastrophic devastation.

"If the gas cloud somehow finds an ignition source we could be looking at complete destruction.

"We really are in the realms of the unknown. The urgent need is to find a way of stopping the gas."

French energy giant Total could have to drill a relief well to plug the leak, which may have come from a disused well next to the one that is currently active.

Safety manager David Hainsworth said a relief well could take six months to drill  but added there were other faster options. He said: "The best-case scenario is the gas dies off in the coming days."

Shell has moved non-essential staff from its platforms about four miles from Elgin.

BP drilled relief wells to permanently seal the Deepwater Horizon platform after the Gulf Of Mexico oil leak disaster two years ago.

By then the platform had been leaking for three months  pouring almost five million barrels of oil into the ocean. Total shares fell seven per cent yesterday. Wholesale gas prices leapt four per cent.

steve.hawkes@the-sun.co.uk



myView



By STEVE HAWKES, Business Editor

TOTAL made almost £8billion last year  and now is not the time for cutting corners.

The French giant needs to throw money at finding and fixing a problem that threatens to turn a small gas leak into the biggest North Sea disaster since the Piper Alpha blast.

Mistakes happen. But in a multi-billion dollar industry, a dodgy cement job (the likely cause here) doesn't look good.

Just ask BP, which blamed the same thing for the biggest oil spill in US history two years ago.

If cost-cutting is found to be the problem, the authorities must throw the book at our French cousins.

image.caption: North Sea gas leak ... Total's Elgin platform (inset, BP's oil platform blazes after 2010 leak)

article.caption: 'Well from hell' gas leak fears

pages.subdeck: Strapped in ... pilot tied up with seat belts
pages.headline: Captain goes crazy on plane
pages.teaser: Captain goes crazy on plane
pages.articlebody:
A PILOT was wrestled to the floor by passengers yesterday  after running around a packed jet shouting: "We're all going down  say your prayers."

Captain Clayton Osborn bellowed about "bombs" and "al-Qaeda" before being restrained.

The 135-passenger Airbus A320 plane was forced into an emergency landing.

Captain Osborn had been locked out of the cockpit by a co-pilot concerned about his erratic behaviour when he left to use the bathroom.

After his outburst, a flight attendant appealed for help. Passengers leapt out of their seats and grabbed the captain before pinning him to the floor for 15 minutes.

Ex-prison officer David Gonzalez said: "I told him 'I'm gonna show you what Iran is like' and grabbed him. I choked him with my forearm. I let go and tackled him to the floor. We were afraid he'd wake up. He was a very large man."

Osborn is said to have passed out and was tied up with seat-belts. Passenger Tiffany Le, 26, said: "People around me were freaking out. A girl said 'Oh my God, what If I never talk to my fiancé again?'"

The New York to Las Vegas flight diverted and landed in Amarillo, Texas.



The pilot yelled the words "Afghanistan" and "Israel" when taken off the jet.

Airline JetBlue described the incident as a "medical situation involving the captain". They said he was removed and taken to a medical facility. The FBI is investigating.

m.wilkinson@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Strapped in ... pilot tied up with seat belts

video.caption: PLANE diverted due to what was described as a 'medical situation' involving the captain

pages.subdeck: Terror ... 2001 attacks
pages.headline: 'Spy war cost 9/11 warning'
pages.teaser: AMERICA may have missed opportunities to prevent 9/11 due to a CIA and FBI 'turf war'
pages.articlebody:
AMERICA may have missed opportunities to prevent 9/11 because of a "turf war" between the CIA and the FBI.

Tory MP David Davis claimed the rival agencies spent more than 12 months arguing about who should tap Afghanistan's phone system.

As a result nothing was in place to monitor calls before terror attacks killed nearly 3,000 people on September 11, 2001.

Former Shadow Home Secretary Mr Davis made the explosive claims under parliamentary privilege in the Commons.

He said: "The FBI and CIA spent more than a year fighting over who should be in charge."

image.caption: Terror ... 2001 attacks

CIA & MI5 agents in Ireland hunting Olympic terror threat
Bin Laden hid terror codes in the Bible

pages.subdeck: Personal friends ... Mr Hague
pages.headline: Hague's dinners for 3 donors
pages.teaser: THE Foreign Secretary hosted multi-millionaire Tory donors at his grace and favour pad
pages.byline: By TOM NEWTON DUNN and GRAEME WILSON
pages.articlebody:
WILLIAM Hague wined and dined three multi-millionaire Tory donors at his country mansion.

The Foreign Secretary hosted the fat cats at grace and favour pad Chevening.

He is the fourth Cabinet minister to be sucked into the cash for access scandal  after the PM, Deputy PM Nick Clegg and Chancellor George Osborne. Ex-Tory leader Mr Hague entertained the party's biggest donor Lord Ashcroft twice at his Kent mansion.

The peer gave the Tories almost £5million from 2005 to 2010. Financier Howard Leigh dined there twice and property tycoon Malcolm Scott was also a guest.

But the three were invited in a personal capacity as Mr Hague's friends rather than specifically as donors, aides insisted. All the dinners between August 2010 and May 2011 were paid for out of Mr Hague's pocket, they added.

Labour stepped up its call for a police probe into the scandal sparked by a newspaper sting on ex-Tory co-treasurer Peter Cruddas. Labour leader Ed Miliband also caved in to a Tory demand yesterday to publish a list of donors he has dined with. Some Tories JOKED about the storm.

London mayor Boris Johnson told a No10 reception: "I want to thank Dave for allowing me in."

Ministers are urging the PM to press ahead with new laws to limit donations to £50,000  including those from unions.

t.newtondunn@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Personal friends ... Mr Hague

article.caption: Chequers in the post
The PM's party list: Details of donor dinners revealed
Cam dine with me

pages.subdeck: Bail ... police saw Bobby Brown talking on his mobile while driving
pages.headline: Whitney Houston's ex Bobby Brown in drink-drive arrest
pages.teaser: SINGER was stopped by cops in LA and failed four sobriety tests before he was bailed
pages.articlebody:
WHITNEY Houston's ex-husband Bobby Brown has been arrested for drink-driving.

The R&B singer, 43, was stopped in Los Angeles when police saw him talking on his mobile.

Cop Tiana Reed said: "We observed intoxication."

Brown failed four sobriety tests and was in custody 90 minutes before being freed on bail. He and Houston  found dead last month aged 48  divorced in 2007.

Brown was jailed for eight days in 1996 for drink-driving.

He was also arrested in 2003 for allegedly hitting Houston.

pages.subdeck: Twitter response ... Madonna denies referencing MDMA
pages.headline: Madonna drug denial
pages.teaser: QUEEN of pop asked concert-goers 'How many people in this crowd have seen Molly?'  slang for MDMA or ecstasy
pages.articlebody:
MADONNA has denied glamorising drug use on stage.

The 53-year-old asked gig-goers in Miami: "How many people in this crowd have seen Molly?"  slang for MDMA or ecstasy.

DJ Deadmau5 branded her an "idiot". But Madge went on Twitter to deny referencing the drug.

She wrote: "I don't support drug use and never have. I was referring to the song Have You Seen Molly written by my friend Cedric Gervais."

He wrote back: "Be a little more aware of what you should represent  and I'll watch my mouth."

pages.subdeck: Vital ... DSK and hooker
pages.headline: Vice girl pic 'will put DSK in prison'
pages.teaser: A PHOTO allegedly showing him with a hooker suggests he was part of a pimping ring
pages.articlebody:
A PHOTO allegedly showing finance boss Dominique Strauss-Kahn with a hooker proves he was part of a prostitute pimping ring, say prosecutors.

The picture is said to feature the ex-IMF chief posing in his office with a brunette call girl known as Jade. Both are fully clothed.

Strauss-Kahn, 62, once tipped to be French president, admits taking part in orgies but insists he did not know the women were hookers because he only saw them naked.

Jade, in her 20s, and several other women claim they regularly had sex with Strauss-Kahn as they travelled around the world with him.

Strauss-Kahn has been charged in Lille, Northern France, with "complicity in pimping". He faces up to 20 years jail if found guilty.

He also faces a civil case in New York for allegedly trying to rape a hotel maid.

image.caption: Vital ... DSK and hooker

pages.subdeck: Dream machine ... Manof takes a nap
pages.headline: Sleeper car
pages.teaser: HERE'S a little boy going flat out in a supercar  the only place he can get to sleep
pages.byline: From GARY O’SHEA in Kuwait City
pages.articlebody:
HERE'S a three-year-old flat out in a Ferrari  the only place he can nod off.

Telecoms tycoon Sheik Jassim Al Wathiqi takes son Manof for a spin every afternoon and evening in the £380,000 458 Spider to help the boisterous lad get some shut-eye.

Sheik Jassim, 40, said: "It works every time. Just five minutes in the Ferrari and he is completely knocked out."

The mega-rich businessman, who has a fleet of flash motors, added: "No other car sends him to sleep. I think it's the vibration from the Ferrari's exhaust that does it."

Sheik Jassim, who lives in Kuwait City, bought the 198mph Spider after car-mad Manof spotted it in a catalogue.

It was sold by the Refined Marques dealership in Cannes, France  whose boss Ahmed Al-Bakry joked: "I've heard a Ferrari called the stuff of dreams but this is ridiculous."

g.oshea@ the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Dream machine ... Manof takes a nap

video.caption: TELECOMS tycoon drives son around in supercar before bedtime

pages.subdeck: Better paid ... police officers
pages.headline: Pay is 8% higher in state jobs
pages.teaser: PUBLIC sector workers are paid 8.2% more per hour than people in private sector
pages.byline: By GRAEME WILSON, Deputy Political Editor, and STEVE HAWKES, Business Editor
pages.articlebody:
PUBLIC sector workers are paid 8.2 per cent more per hour than people in the private sector, official figures revealed yesterday.

The difference is the BIGGEST in the last ten years.

The gap has almost trebled since 2002  when public sector workers were paid just three per cent more.

It follows years of big salary rises for public sector workers before recent pay freezes. In contrast, millions of private sector staff have been hit by pay cuts in recent years.

The figures from the Office for National Statistics emerged less than a week after Chancellor George Osborne raised the prospect of scrapping national pay deals in the public sector.

Ministers fear private firms in the North and Midlands are struggling to compete with generous pay rates offered in health, education and local councils.

Officials have been ordered to look at whether a system of regional pay agreements could tackle the problem.

This could see teachers or nurses in the North East getting paid less than counterparts in the South East.

The ONS said the huge pay gap could be partly explained by the fact public sector workers tended to be older and better qualified.

Matthew Elliott, chief executive of the TaxPayers' Alliance, said: "Unions need to accept reforms to salaries and generous pensions. Private sector staff have seen changes to what they receive since the recession, they shouldn't subsidise excessive deals for the public sector."

But TUC general secretary Brendan Barber said: "The analysis would be more accurate if all the bonuses paid out to private sector employees  especially sky-high payouts to top bankers  were included."

g.wilson@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Better paid ... police officers

pages.subdeck: Games star ... Gunnell
pages.headline: Olympic flag ban hits Sally Gunnell
pages.teaser: ATHLETICS legend Sally Gunnell banned from flying Union Flag to avoid BA upset
pages.articlebody:
ATHLETICS legend Sally Gunnell was banned from flying the Union Flag while promoting London 2012 yesterday  to avoid upsetting sponsors British Airways.

Hurdler Sally, in the Barcelona stadium where she won gold in 1992, wanted to recreate the iconic image of her celebrating with the flag.

But organisers stopped her because she represents BA's rivals easyJet.

BA paid £80million to sponsor London 2012. One of the event's planners said: "There is an exhaustive list of what Sally can and cannot do.

"It might raise eyebrows but otherwise the £80million spent by BA is a waste of money."

  • A FRENCH tourism campaign designed to lure Britons across the Channel during the Olympics is using pictures of a South African beach.

    British ad firm The Line Agency, responsible for the Tube posters, apologised for the error.

image.caption: Games star ... Gunnell

pages.subdeck: Mancini ... 'God's not helped me with my career - he has more important things to do'
pages.headline: Pilgrim Mancini is not praying
pages.teaser: MAN City manager makes pilgrimage to holy site  but is not praying to win the league
pages.articlebody:
MAN City manager Roberto Mancini has made a pilgrimage to a holy site  but NOT to pray for the Blues to win the Premier League.

The devout Italian, 47, jetted to a village where Catholics say the Virgin Mary miraculously appeared to six schoolchildren.

Mancini said he was there "as a pilgrim" after his father Aldo, 76, recovered from a heart attack.

And he believes City can still win the title without any help from above.

He said: "I have been very religious since I was a young boy. But I would not say that God or the Virgin Mary help me in my career. They have more important stuff to do.

"But I believe Manchester City will win the league."

Former altar boy Mancini also went to mass and visited a monastery on his two-day trip to Medjugorje in Bosnia-Herzegovina with wife Federica and daughter Camilla.

But the highlight was walking to the top of Apparition Hill where the six children  now know as "seers"  had their vision of Mary in 1981.

Mancini met two of the seers but refused to say what they had talked about.

His mother Marina  who missed the pilgrimage  said: "You don't go to a shrine to ask for help with football but for more serious matters such as health.

"You can't ask the Virgin Mary to help you win a football championship. That would not be right."

Mancini's stay at the holy site could not stop arch-rivals Manchester United from opening up a three-point gap at the top of the league.

The City boss went to an Irish bar to see the Red Devils beat Fulham 1-0 on Monday night.

One local said: "If he'd been praying for a miracle, it hasn't been granted. He had a face like thunder.

"He looked tense all the way through the match  but didn't stay for very long after the final whistle."

Mancini  who flew home on a private jet last night  knows some things are beyond a miracle. Like a referee awarding a penalty against United at Old Trafford...

g.patrick@the-sun.co.uk

pages.subdeck: Rare ... black fox
pages.headline: Brush with a black fox
pages.teaser: ANIMAL is caught on camera roaming in Herts  1 of only a handful believed to exist in UK
pages.articlebody:
A RARE black fox is caught on camera roaming the British countryside  one of only a handful believed to exist here.

The shots were taken by amateur photographer John Moore, 58, to prove to his mates he really had seen the "mythical" creature.

It is actually a red fox that has kept its dark cub's coat due to a genetic flaw. Legend has it they bring disaster. But John, who saw it near his home in Bassingbourn, Herts, reckons he is lucky. He said: "I didn't realise how rare it was. From these photos there's no mistaking it."

image.caption: Rare ... black fox

pages.subdeck: Susan Millman ... sex texts
pages.headline: Woman jailed for sex with boy of 15
pages.teaser: A woman of 47 has been banged up after having sex with the boy in her Jeep
pages.articlebody:
A WOMAN of 47 has been jailed after having sex with a 15-year-old boy in her Jeep.

Married Susan Millman sobbed as she admitted twice having intercourse with the underage lad  once after he sneaked out of his bedroom window.

She had also flashed her chest to other boys and offered sex via a webcam.

Millman first chatted to the 15-year-old on Facebook and he "unburdened" after rows with his mum.

But she then commented on his "good looks" and began bombarding him with sexual texts, Grimsby Crown Court heard.

Prosecutor James Byatt said: "There were so many he asked her to stop it when he was at school."

Millman told police they had only kissed, saying: "He's bubbly, like me."

Jailing her for 18 months, Judge David Tremberg said: "You were in a position of trust."

Her hubby, who works long hours at his coach firm, is standing by her.

image.caption: Susan Millman ... sex texts

article.caption: Underage sex mum faces jail

pages.subdeck: So brave ... Captain Lisa Head
pages.headline: Lisa inquest praises bravery
pages.teaser: CAPTAIN Lisa Head was only second woman killed while serving in Afghanistan
pages.articlebody:
A FEARLESS bomb disposal expert died after she returned to the scene of an explosion to help secure a village.

Captain Lisa Head, 29, became only the second female member of our Armed Forces in Afghanistan to be killed in nearly a decade.

Capt Head  of 11 Explosive Ordnance Disposal Regiment, the Royal Logistic Corps  had been blown off her feet when an undetected IED in an alley partially detonated under her foot on April 18 last year.

She was knocked to the ground but got up and, after gathering her courage, returned to the alley in Padaka, Helmand, where she was then blown up by a booby trap.

An inquest held at Bradford Coroner's Court heard how her unit did a similar job to that portrayed in Oscar-winning movie The Hurt Locker.

And Capt Head's comrade Corporal Adam Tucker told the court about her final moments, saying she had made safe one bomb before a second one knocked her off her feet.

He said she returned to their vehicle, smoked "a few cigarettes and made light of it".

Cpl Tucker added: "Being the stubborn Yorkshire woman that she was, she said she was quite happy to continue and went back down the alley."

While defusing a second IED, she knelt down and triggered a third five kilogram device that blew off both her legs, right arm and the fingers on her left hand.

Cpl Tucker and colleagues raced down the alley, applied emergency dressings and called in a helicopter.

Capt Head of Huddersfield, West Yorks, was taken to hospital at Camp Bastion, then flown to the Queen Elizabeth military hospital in Birmingham, where she died on April 19.

Recording a verdict of unlawful killing, Bradford Coroner Prof Paul Marks paid tribute to the soldier.

He said: "I cannot praise too highly the courage of Lisa Head."

image.caption: So brave ... Captain Lisa Head

pages.subdeck: Frightening scene ... Camilla points gun
pages.headline: Stick 'em up!
pages.teaser: BUT don't worry it was only the Duchess playing around with a replica pistol from The Killing
pages.articlebody:
THE Duchess of Cornwall confessed to being "addicted" to crime drama The Killing as she posed with a gun on the set of the Danish hit show today.

Camilla had requested a trip to see filming in a scrapyard outside Copenhagen, Denmark, on the final day of her eight-day tour of Scandinavia with the Prince of Wales.

The Duchess, who borrowed show star Sofie Grabol's weapon, confessed: "I'm an addict. I'm so excited by this."

It came after Charles revealed that his wife had introduced him to the detective show.

But while she got a sneak peek at the latest series, he went to a nearby housing estate.

Series creator Soren Sveistrup had met the couple yesterday at a reception hosted by the British ambassador.

He said: "Royalty is not the kind of audience you would expect. Prince Charles told me that it was Camilla who introduced him to The Killing.

"He said it was one of the only things they could agree on seeing together."

The Duchess appeared fascinated by the replica gun used by actress Sofie, who plays detective Sarah Lund.

And she asked if it was REAL.

Grabol told her: "It is just a toy gun. It weighs nothing."

As Camilla waved it around, she joked: "It was me all along."

Sarah Lund is known for her Faroe Island knitwear and Camilla was given her very own classic jumper.

Sofie said: "I think it is really surreal. But it's lovely that she wanted to come here.

"I told her last night to wear flat shoes. This is not really an inviting place for a royal visit.

"When I met the Duchess she was just so lovely to talk to."

Camilla also met actor Nikolaj Kaas, who plays a secret service agent working with Lund.

Referring to the fact two of Lund's previous colleagues have been killed in the first two series, the Duchess told him: "I hope we are going to see you again.

"I hope you don't go the same way as the others."

image.caption: Frightening scene ... Camilla points gun

pages.headline: Upper crust
pages.teaser: READ The Sun Says leader comment to see our take on pressing issues of the day
pages.articlebody:
NOT a vote has been cast and already the Tories have managed to get taxes down.

Labour's surrender on 10 per cent extra cider duty is a triumph for David Cameron.

The Tories also blocked Labour's planned broadband tax.

Not a bad start as the Tories were clear winners on Day One of the election campaign.

In the Commons, Mr Cameron exposed Gordon Brown's weasel words over Labour's jobs tax.

Mr Brown says the business world has been deceived by the Tories into thinking that Labour's National Insurance tax rise will cost jobs.

Business leaders say Mr Brown is patronising, "economically illiterate" and insults their intelligence.

Almost seventy of Britain's biggest employers  including one of Mr Brown's own advisers  say the Tories are RIGHT.

The Sun agrees. Making firms pay more in tax for every person hired means bosses take on fewer workers.

Only in the warped world of Gordon Brown does raising National Insurance help unemployment.

The fed-up business community has washed its hands of union-run Labour.

Employers think that there will be more REAL jobs under the Tories.

Exactly what the country needs to hear.

Blaze heroes

FIREMEN didn't hesitate when they arrived at a blazing block of high-rise flats.

They plunged straight in  and two tragically lost their lives.

The Sun pays tribute to Hampshire fire heroes James Shears and Alan Bannon.

The brave men and women of our emergency services are very special.

When it comes to the crunch, they lay their lives on the line for us.

We are very lucky. We should be grateful and never forget their sacrifice.

Brave champ

TENNIS ace Martina Navratilova faces another tough challenge.

The legendary champ is diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 53.

Not even a superfit athlete like Martina is safe from a cancer that affects women indiscriminately.

Many Sun readers will have a relative or friend who has been struck down.

Cancer survival rates in Britain have improved over the years. But they lag behind much of Europe and America, where Martina is optimistic about her prospects.

Yes, times are tough. But our next Government must do much more to improve our record on survival rates for breast and other cancers.

Brave Martina, who never gave up on court, will not give up on this fight either.

pages.subdeck: Clear skies ... Nasa satellite image
pages.headline: Brightish isles
pages.teaser: BRITAIN is basking under virtually no clouds in an amazingly sharp NASA snap
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN basks under virtually cloudless skies in this amazingly clear Nasa satellite snap.

It was taken at lunchtime yesterday  the sixth day of record-breaking temperatures.

The picture shows just a faintest wisp of cloud along the Norfolk coast.

Also visible is a column of smoke rising from South Wales  one of 291 reports of grass fires this week.

A huge blaze ripped across 15 acres of tinder-dry hillsides near Newport and another swept Denbigh Moors in North Wales.

Around 70 firefighters tackled an overnight blaze at Kirbean near Dumfries, Scotland, which could be seen 30 miles away.

East Yorkshire joined 14 other counties  home to a total of 22 million people  in being declared officially in drought. Parts have seen the driest 12 months since 1910 with river levels continuing to fall, the Environment Agency said.

A spokeswoman warned: "This won't be the last area to go into drought, it is simply the latest."

Top temperature yesterday was 23.6°C (74.4°F) at Aboyne, Aberdeenshire. Today could see similar figures in England. It will cool over the weekend but there will still be no sign of much-needed rain.

b.jackson@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Clear skies ... Nasa satellite image

pages.subdeck: Demands ... taxman
pages.headline: Aged raided: OAPs tell of tax torment
pages.teaser: THE biggest tax blunder for a generation can be laid bare by Sun City after pensioners report threats from taxman
pages.articlebody:
THE sheer scale of the biggest tax blunder for a generation can be laid bare by Sun City today.

An unprecedented number of pensioners have called The Sun after getting threatening demands from the taxman  despite never knowingly underpaying tax.

Bosses at Her Majesty's Revenue & Customs warned in November that 1.2million people had underpaid tax because their tax codes were never changed when they retired or took new jobs.

Of these, it is estimated that 150,000 pensioners could be affected.

The demands are now beginning to drop, stunning pensioners across the UK.

Grannies struggling to make ends meet have spent hours trying to reach the taxman's call centre staff.

Others, on getting through, have got the WRONG advice.

Gary Chambers, 68, of Ely, Cambs, said: "I retired in 2008 but got a demand for £1,912 in January.

"Two reviews and a complaint later, I'm still waiting for the outcome."

Frustrated pensioners claim they are being given the cold shoulder and have no idea whether they actually owe the money or whether to pay.

Insiders admit part of the problem seems to come from the taxman failing to pick up when people start drawing on savings  or change jobs.

Red-faced HMRC chief executive Lin Homer last night apologised.

She said: "Since recently taking over I have found that the customer service we give is getting better but it's not nearly good enough."

TaxPayers' Alliance chief exec Matthew Elliot called for a "simpler tax system".

He blasted: "Britain's overly complicated tax system is too taxing for the taxman. It's ordinary people who are paying the price.

"The constant bungles at HMRC are resulting in pensioners and other hard-pressed taxpayers facing demands for cash that they can barely afford."

The scandal comes a week after Chancellor George Osborne raided grannies' pensions in the Budget  by freezing their allowances.



Roy Chambers

ROY retired in 1999 but has just received a tax demand for £553.90.

The 78-year-old of Llandudno, North Wales, said: "I asked about my tax code and it related to a South African company I'd never heard of. I've got to pay.

"I'm appalled. It's affecting my health. I've never had trouble with tax before."



Maureen Pasterfield

FURIOUS Maureen says she is "spitting feathers" after being asked for £2,500 by the Taxman.

The demand dates back four years. Maureen, of Middleton-on-Sea, West Sussex, complained: "I'm being taxed 43 per cent of my income next year. I work part-time and earn about £12,500 a year. I'm steaming."



Helen Clemance

HELEN retired due to ill health and is now drawing her late husband's pension.

The 59-year-old of Wednesbury, West Midlands, was met with a demand for £2,900  and was asked to repay £80 a month.

She said: "I don't know how I'm going to survive. I have got a mortgage to pay."



Philip Mason

FRUSTRATED Philip has been told he must cough up £580.

The 69-year-old has been left tearing his hair out in Bracknell, Berks.

He explained: "I was laid-off last year. They said I earned £32,000.

"I have never earned that in my life. They incorrectly claim that I have got SIX pensions."



Ian Carneoo

IAN told of his frustration after getting a demand for £231.20.

The 60-year-old, of Tamworth, Staffs, said: "I haven't got a clue whether I owe it or not. When I got through the woman was very rude and abusive.

"'All we do is collect tax', she said, and told me not to be so abrupt."



Keith Alexander Thomas

KEITH was "shaken to the core" by his demand.

The hard-of-hearing 73-year-old of Gislingham, Suffolk, was told to pay £4,500 for underpayment from 2008 to 2011.

Daughter Dawn said: "Dad is terribly upset. He is not in great health and I've been writing on his behalf and trying to get them to sort it out."



Big firms in 'let-off'

THE taxman's relentless pursuit of the elderly comes as it fights accusations of letting big name companies off the hook for BILLIONS.

The National Audit Office said in December it wanted to look at up to ten "cosy" deals involving large companies.

The move followed claims that Revenue and Customs chief Dave Hartnett had failed to collect £25.5billion from big business.

MPs heard allegations that VODAFONE should have paid £6billion in tax  when it was only charged for £1.25billion.

GOLDMAN SACHS was "let off" £20million, it was claimed. HMRC defended itself vigorously.

But Mr Hartnett is due to retire this summer  with a gold-plated pension pot.

As for pensioners? They should turn to three charities: Tax Help for Older People on 0845 601 3321, the Low Income Tax Reform Group or TaxAid.



myView

By STEVE HAWKES

WE get lots of calls at Sun City, but no single issue has sparked such fury, anger and sheer desperation as this.

It's so easy for those in a cosy high-powered role to

forget Joe Public.

But just imagine the stress a pensioner feels when a demand for cash arrives out of the blue.

Then, when they try to find out more, there's the pain of being passed from pillar to post by call centre workers.

This outrage should shame Revenue and Customs.

One doubts, though, it will change the way they behave.



World thirsty for our whisky

THE WORLD is turning to Scotch  with whisky exports soaring to record levels of more than £4BILLION.

Scotch sales abroad soared 23 per cent, with the fastest-growing market  Brazil  up a thumping 48 per cent.

The Brazilian city of Recife is believed to have the highest per capita consumption of whisky in the world. Tipplers in Singapore and Taiwan were nearly as thirsty  with growth there of 44 per cent.

The Scotch Whisky Association says members now contribute £134 a SECOND to Britain's balance of trade.

SWA chief Gavin Hewitt said: "Scotch whisky continues to meet increasing demand from all corners of the globe. And it is being enjoyed by younger professionals in newer markets in Asia and Latin America."

Spirits group DIAGEO has boasted for the past year of growth in its big-name brands. It has opened two posh Johnnie Walker bars in China, where the whisky goes up in quality and price as you move to higher floors in the club.

The Food and Drink Federation says food and soft drink exports hit £12billion last year  up ten per cent.



18% Asda be record

ASDA has grabbed a record share of Britain's grocery market  almost 18 per cent.

Sales at the supermarket giant were 8.1 per cent up on last year in the four weeks to March 18, industry figures show.

Boosted by the integration of NETTO, Asda's share is now 17.7 per cent. Asda's sales growth compared with 6.4 per cent at MORRISONS, 4.9 per cent at TESCO, and 4.6 per cent at SAINSBURY'S.

The CO-OP recorded another month of falling sales, down 1.4 per cent.

Analysts KANTAR said: "It's good reading for Asda."



War is hell for Leather

IMPERIAL Leather maker PZ CUSSONS has slashed profit forecasts after chaos in Nigeria, where it has operated since the 19th century.

PZ said the ongoing religious conflict in the north of the country meant upcoming results would be "some way below expectations".

Shares in the group, which also makes Carex hand wash and owns the Sanctuary Spa, crashed ten per cent to 301.30p.

The company dates back to a trading post in Sierra Leone in 1879. Paterson Zochonis opened a branch in Nigeria in 1899.



US market is building

BUILDING materials giant WOLSELEY says the American market is on the mend  as clients in Europe continue to cut back.

The owner of PLUMB CENTER upped its shareholder dividend by a third yesterday as the recovery in the US gathers pace.

About half of Wolseley's revenues come from the other side of the Atlantic.

Boss Ian Meakins said: "There's no doubt that consumer confidence in the US has come back quickly."

Half-year profits rose 28 per cent to £250million on sales of £6.8billion.



Window clean-up

HOMEOWNERS forking out for new windows and doors could avoid shoddy tradesmen with a new website.

MyGlass.org.uk, which lets customers rate installers for quality, has been launched by The Double Glazing & Conservatory Ombudsman Scheme.

It is backed by Crimewatch's Nick Ross, who says it will help "tell the good guys from the cowboys". The industry acted after pressure from Trading Standards, consumer group Which? and the government's Constitutional Affairs Department. Ombudsman decisions have the same power as a court judgment.

But the move comes too late for Brad Scott-James, 50, of Bardney, Lincs  who spent three years and £150,000 on a legal fight over shoddy glazing work.

A recent survey found that 86 per cent of consumer complaints in the last five years were due to poor workmanship.

image.caption: Demands ... taxman

article.caption: Pasty tax gets a pasting
Bandit George has robbed our bandits
£400 tax cut for ordinary workers

pages.subdeck: Healthy ... Natasha with Rose and bag
pages.headline: The plastic bab
pages.teaser: TINY Rose Lansbury was placed in a sandwich bag, which worked as an incubator
pages.articlebody:
TINY Rose Lansbury was saved by a SANDWICH BAG  after she was born weighing just 1lb.

The battling baby was put straight into the plastic bag that acted as an incubator after she was delivered by emergency caesarean.

Docs were forced to act quickly in hospital after mum Natasha had a 28-week scan that showed Rose had stopped growing and was the size of an apple.

Natasha, 26, said: "I cried when I saw her in the plastic bag. I didn't understand what they were doing. I thought she was going to die.

"She was rushed away to the special care baby unit where she was surrounded by machinery and monitors. But I was told it was the sandwich bag that saved her.

"It kept her warm until they could get her into the incubator."

Full-time mum Natasha  who has a son Alfie, seven  spent three months by Rose's bedside at Barnet Hospital, Herts, where the girl needed a machine to breathe.

She is now a healthy six-month-old although she still weighs just 9½lb  the same as a newborn.

Natasha, of Potters Bar, Herts, added: "She is a bundle of joy. It's amazing that something that everyone has in their kitchen drawer helped save her. When she goes to school I'll tell her she used to be the size of her sandwiches."

Sun Doctor Carol Cooper said: "A special care baby unit can't do any good if a child doesn't get there in time. Premature babies need warmth. Without it, they can die.

"That's what made the sandwich bag a good emergency vehicle for Rose.

rachel.dale@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Healthy ... Natasha with Rose and bag

video.caption: GROWN man wears nappies, sleeps in cot...and is looking for a new mum

article.caption: Miracle triple transplant Mum gives birth

pages.subdeck: Huge bier ... men take it in turns to carry the king's body
pages.headline: The Tong goodbye
pages.teaser: MEN wearing traditional skirts held a huge bier carrying the body of King George Tupou V
pages.articlebody:
A PROCESSION of 1,000 men take turns to carry the body of the King of Tonga on a huge bier yesterday.

The men  many wearing traditional skirts  marched from his palace to the royal tombs.

They were flanked by 5,000 children including schoolgirls who sat patiently for hours in the burial grounds. King George Tupou V, pictured inset, died ten days ago, aged 63.

He was popular for introducing sweeping political reforms to the hard-up Pacific island, which has a population of just 106,000. He will be succeeded by his more conservative younger brother Tupou VI.

image.caption: Huge bier ... men take it in turns to carry the king's body

pages.subdeck: Fanatic ... maniac Merah
pages.headline: Massacre nut 'spied on terrorists for France'
pages.teaser: GUNMAN whose 7 victims included 3 children was spy for the country, it is claimed
pages.articlebody:
THE massacre gunman whose seven victims included three kids at a French school was a spy for the country, it was claimed yesterday.

Twisted Mohamed Merah, 23, was recruited by France's DGSE intelligence agency as he travelled to Israel, Jordan and Afghanistan in 2010, according to Italian media.

His alleged role as an informant last night fuelled fury at security services for leaving the known Muslim fanatic free to launch his murderous rampage.

Merah  cornered by cops in Toulouse and shot dead last week  was said to have been seen as "the kind of young man who could infiltrate terrorist training camps".

If true, that may have backfired  with his experiences converting him to al-Qaeda. Merah filmed himself shooting the kids at a Toulouse Jewish school who died along with a rabbi  days after he killed three soldiers.

The Paris office of Arabic TV network Al-Jazeera was sent footage pointing to an accomplice. Merah's brother has been held but fears grew a third terrorist was involved. Al-Jazeera refused to air the vile film.

Yesterday Merah's dad, a convicted drug dealer living in Algeria, vowed to sue the French government for damages over his son's shoot-out death.

French foreign secretary Alain Juppe raged: "If I was the father of a monster like that, I'd shut up out of shame."

n.parker@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Fanatic ... maniac Merah

pages.articlebody:

The singer tampered with her mug before these latest promo shots.

She covers her modesty with a piece of paper with "immigrant" written on the front.

Thankfully, the snapper didn't use drawing pins to keep it upright.

pages.subdeck: 'Amy still loved him when she died' ... Winehouse with Blake Fielder-Civil in 2007
pages.headline: Blake won't get a penny of Amy Winehouse's £3m
pages.teaser: TRAGIC star did not leave a will so her parents will receive all of her cash after tax & bills
pages.articlebody:
TRAGIC Amy Winehouse left a £3million fortune  but not a penny for junkie ex-husband Blake Fielder-Civil, The Sun can reveal.

The Back to Black singer had over £4,257,580 in assets when she died following a drink binge last July.

She did not leave a will, so the £2,944,554 remaining after tax and bills goes to her parents Mitch and Janis, probate documents show.

It means Blake, 29  blamed by Mitch for introducing his daughter to heroin and cocaine  will not get any of Amy's estate.

A friend of the late star said: "There aren't many 27-year-olds that make a will  and Amy didn't either.

"She had no idea how much money she had and it certainly wasn't the top of her priority list.

"Had she made a will, Blake may have well been left something  not cash, perhaps an investment. Amy still loved him when she died.

"The way things are, Mitch and Janis have been handed the estate.

"They're sensible and shrewd so it's probably for the best Blake doesn't get anything."

Amy and Blake married in May 2007 and divorced in July 2009.

After finding fame, Amy was estimated to be worth £10million  raising questions about what happened to all her cash. When she died she had two companies  Cherry Westfield and CW Touring.

Cherry Westfield was worth £2,004,963. CW Touring had whittled down to a worth of just £8,032 compared with £142,012 in 2009.

The pal added: "You could have burned a pile of her cash in front of her and she would have lit a cigarette off the embers."

Amy died of alcohol poisoning in her London home.

r.white@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: 'Amy still loved him when she died' ... Winehouse with Blake Fielder-Civil in 2007

pages.subdeck: Dress will impress ... Kate Winslet at London premiere for new, 3D version of Titanic
pages.headline: Kate's plunging neckline at Titanic re-launch
pages.teaser: BRIT beauty wows onlookers at premiere for re-release of the blockbuster that made her a star
pages.articlebody:
TITANIC star Kate Winslet has that sinking feeling last night  at the prospect of being seen naked in 3D.

Kate, 36, was at the London premiere of the 3D version of 1997 hit Titanic, in which she stripped for a sex scene with co-star Leonardo DiCaprio.

The Oscar winner said: "I'm not going to look. I'll be in the bar by that point. I wish I hadn't shown so much flesh but I was young and I knew I had things to prove."

But Kate said she will be happy to watch herself on screen with her two kids  Mia, 11, and Joe, eight.

The Brit beauty looked gorgeous as she attended the screening in a floor-length black gown, with glittering silver shoulders and stomach-detail adding a touch of glamour.

And the 36-year-old blonde topped off the sophisticated look with matching jewellery, adding a silver bracelet and earrings.

She took the time to sign autographs for fans at the Royal Albert Hall in Kensington, west London.

Her Titanic role, as socialite Rose DeWitt Bukater opposite Leonardo DiCaprio's Jack Dawson, launched her career 15 years ago.

Their doomed relationship against the backdrop of the liner's sinking that claimed 1,517 lives made the film one of the most successful of all time.

The film bagged an incredible 11 Oscars, as well as raking in a massive £1.14bn at the box office  making it the biggest ever earner until 2009's Avatar.

She was joined on the red carpet by co-star Billy Zane, as well as the film's director, James Cameron.

Cameron this week became the first person to make a solo journey to the deepest point of the ocean's floor  almost seven miles below the surface.

He said of the new, 3D version of his film: "The 3D enriches all of Titanic's most thrilling moments and its most emotional moments.

"More than ever, you feel you're right there going through all the jeopardy that Jack and Rose go through.

"The 3D kicks the whole experience up to another level."

The re-release marks 100 years since the doomed passenger liner set sail from Southampton to New York in 1912.

image.caption: Dress will impress ... Kate Winslet at London premiere for new, 3D version of Titanic

pages.subdeck: Is it Ri-lly her? ... the star totters through the Underground
pages.headline: Rihanna sexes up the Tube
pages.teaser: RIHANNA rides the Tube to see Drake concert in thigh-high leather boots
pages.articlebody:
FLAMIN' heck! Rihanna is at it again  jumping on yet another London Tube.

But this time the singer treated lucky commuters to a thigh-ful as she took to the Underground in a pair of eye-popping leather boots.

The multi-millionaire left onlookers gobsmacked as she waited with pals to board at Waterloo Station after buying her own regular ticket.

Wearing a pair of bondage-inspired boots, a leather jacket and a flame-patterned T-shirt, she couldn't have looked any more out of place as she made her way to see Drake at the O2 Arena last night.

But that wouldn't have bothered many of her fellow passengers as she accessorised her look with big red lips, gold hoop earrings, black Ray-Bans and bright blonde hair  and showed off her Barbados behind in tiny hot pants.

Perhaps the star was just making the most of the unseasonably warm British weather.

Earlier in the day she had tweeted: "The weather in London is unreal #LilMissSunshine."

Rihanna is becoming a bit of a regular on the Underground  opting for Britain's public transport system on a number of occasions over heavy London traffic.

Last February she was spotted on the Tube on her way to a BRIT awards rehearsal where she was performing.

And in October she travelled to her own concert at the O2 on the Jubilee line.

pages.headline: Dan Walker is king of the swingers
pages.teaser: FOOTBALL Focus presenter wins Bizarre Masters against a host of stars including Vernon Kay, Sheringham and Regis
pages.articlebody:
TIGER WOODS has just won his first tournament in 30 months.

The inspiring news must have filtered through after heroic efforts by golfers at The Grove in Hertfordshire.

Yes, it was the third annual Bizarre Masters.

The priceless, and by that I mean it is worth absolutely nothing, McMatalan tartan blazer went to Football Focus hero Dan Walker.

The 6ft 4in BBC host played a blinder. His efforts were even more impressive considering his playing partners were Sky Sports News siren Charlotte Jackson and her equally fit TV presenter pal Zoe Hardman.

He is a married man with three children, I should add.

Athletics legend John Regis came second, but then again, he was pretty good at picking up silver during his track career.

Vernon Kay failed to regain his title while England stars Tony Cottee and Teddy Sheringham also missed out.

Darren Gough kept everyone entertained at the 19th hole with stories of visiting gay nightclubs with Freddie Fintoff.

The celebs then battled it out on the new EA Sports Tiger Woods 13 on Xbox Kinect after a few sherries.

It's a great game as you don't use a controller and just swing with kinect. The game is out on Friday.

pages.subdeck: BBattle ... Brian Belo is suing ITV after he alleged they ripped off concept for his show
pages.headline: BB Brian's TOWIE court fight
pages.teaser: EXCLUSIVE: Big Brother's Brian Belo says he should be paid for coming up with show
pages.articlebody:
FORMER Big Brother winner Brian Belo has demanded TOWIE is taken off the air until he is paid for coming up with the idea for the ITV2 show.

The Essex lad is hoping to be awarded £4million if his legal action succeeds.

Brian is suing ITV and producer Lime Pictures after he alleged they ripped off the concept for his show Totally Essex, something which the firms deny.

The format  which was created by Brian and co-claimants Sassy Films and Massive TV  had the same premise as TOWIE and a taster clip even featured Mark Wright, Kirk Norcross and Amy Childs.

Brian claims TOWIE bosses later offered him £2,500 for the rights to his show.

Brian's writ  lodged at the High Court earlier this month  alleges ITV and Lime Pictures have committed breaches of copyright and confidence.

It seeks an injunction stopping ITV from screening TOWIE  which is set to return for a fifth series on April 15  until he, Sassy Films and Massive TV give their permission for it to air.

And they won't do this until a financial settlement is agreed.

Sources claim that Brian  who took the crown on 2007's Big Brother  is banking on a "large swathe of texts and emails" between him and staff at Lime Pictures, which he believes is proof they regarded him as the creator of the show.

One source said the "killer document" is a contract sent to him by Lime Pictures in October 2010 apparently asking him to sign away the rights to TOWIE for £2,500. He is also understood to have included in the writ evidence of texts where he is asked for help with contact details for the original cast of Totally Essex.

ITV and Lime Pictures are vigorously defending the action and said in a joint statement: "The Only Way Is Essex is an original concept created and developed by an award-winning team at Lime Pictures.

"Brian Belo's claim against Lime and ITV is totally without foundation and will be vigorously defended.

"The creative team at Lime Pictures is very proud of TOWIE, and the notion that it was not entirely their own work is a serious allegation which is completely refuted."

TOWIE, which first aired in October 2010, won a Bafta last year and has created some big stars including Mark Wright, who is now attempting to crack the US as a TV presenter.

image.caption: BBattle ... Brian Belo is suing ITV after he alleged they ripped off concept for his show

pages.subdeck: Contestant ... Paddy McGuinness with Essex girl Hannah Reville
pages.headline: Take Me Out girl's taken out
pages.teaser: A CONTESTANT on the hit dating show was axed after romeo hid thuggery charge
pages.byline: By LEIGH HOLMWOOD, Deputy TV Editor
pages.articlebody:
A PRETTY contestant on ITV1's hit dating show Take Me Out was fuming last night  after a romeo who picked her got them both axed for hiding a thuggery conviction.

Fans tuning in next Saturday night will see Hannah Reville, 25, mysteriously missing from the line-up of 30 girls looking to bag a fella.

That is because last week's show edited out the entire sequence in which she was chosen by semi-pro footballer Jarvis Walters, 30.

The couple got to go on a romantic trip to Cyprus  before fresh background checks revealed Hannah's date had a conviction for assaulting a man in a club.

Hannah, from Essex  who had spent six weeks waiting to be picked  was horrified to lose her moment in the spotlight.

She stormed: "He did something wrong  I did nothing."

A pal said after last week's show featured three dates instead of four: "She was so excited when Jarvis picked her. Now she is devastated."

Walters, from Surrey, got a 12-month community order over the 2009 assault. He claimed his date was the "best ever", adding: "Take Me Out have lost out big time."

A spokeswoman for the show, which is hosted by Paddy McGuinness, confirmed: "Jarvis did not declare a conviction that came to light."

pages.subdeck: Beauty ... Britain's Got Talent make-up artist Francesca Neill
pages.headline: BGT babe brings Si out in Cole sweat
pages.teaser: MUSIC mogul has fallen for a new make-up artist  and she looks just like Cheryl Cole
pages.articlebody:
SIMON Cowell has fallen for a new make-up artist  and she's a lookalike of former X Factor judge Cheryl Cole.

The music mogul, understood to have split from make-up artist fiancée Mezhgan Hussainy earlier this year, admitted having the hots for Francesca Neill, who is working as Alesha Dixon's assistant on the new series of Britain's Got Talent.

But Simon says he gets so flustered around the former model  who has dated singer Craig David  that he has not plucked up the courage to speak to her.

He said: "We have the new, cutest make-up artist. But I just can't talk to her, I'm kind of tongue-tied."

Simon was asked by Britain's Got More Talent presenter Stephen Mulhern if he wanted him to put in a good word, but the bashful judge said: "No, that would make it awkward."

Simon's fellow BGT judge, David Walliams, also got involved, telling him: "She's got a boyfriend."

Simon smiled and nodded, saying: "Good." Stephen then tried to wind up Simon by saying: "I hear he's a cagefighter."

A surprised Simon replied: "Great. Is he really? No he's not!"

A pal said: "Simon thinks Francesca is beautiful  and, of course, he has a soft spot for make-up artists."

London-based Francesca was thrilled by Simon's comments after pals saw him talking about her on the BGT spin-off show on Saturday.

One told her on Twitter: "Ooh Simon thinks yr cute!!!" To which Francesca replied: "Hahaha that was so funny x"

Another friend said: "1st time simon has spoken abt a new makeup artist so well done. X". Francesca replied: "Ha thanks hun xx". One outlandish pal messaged her: "Simon totes wants to get in your panties!!!"

Francesca said only in reply: "hahahahaha xxx". Another pal wanted to know if she had given Simon any beauty treatments, asking: "U got hold of Simon's brows yet ;) x". Francesca said: "It's my mission to give Simon some HD brows ;-) x"

As well as working with Alesha, former Miss Manchester and Leeds University graduate Francesca has also done make up for Girls Aloud singer Nadine Coyle, X Factor winner Matt Cardle and rival BBC show Strictly Come Dancing.

Simon admitted in January that he was "on a break" from Mezhgan.

He said: "It's quite a complicated relationship. We have had a break from each other, and we are still incredibly close.

"I'm vulnerable. It's not on, it's not off  it's somewhere in the middle.

"I don't know if I will ever get married, but I am happy."

Simon  who has previously dated Sinitta, Jackie St Claire and Terri Seymour  met Mezhgan on the set of American Idol in 2003, where she did his make-up.

He reportedly proposed two years ago with a £250,000 diamond ring.

Last year he told Piers Morgan on his ITV Life Stories show that Mezhgan was "the one"  something that he later said he regretted.

He said: "I have been pretty good about not talking about my private stuff, but I got caught up in the moment."

image.caption: Beauty ... Britain's Got Talent make-up artist Francesca Neill

pages.headline: Sharon Osbourne: X-it was a mistake
pages.teaser: MUSIC manager has confessed that she was 'dumb' to quit the show
pages.articlebody:
SHARON Osbourne has admitted quitting The X Factor was "dumb".

The music manager officially left the hit talent show in 2008 after a personality clash with Dannii Minogue, who had been invited on to the panel for its fourth series.

Ozzy Osbourne's wife Sharon confessed: "It was a dumb move, but emotionally right.

"It was a huge show, it paid so well, so much came from it. But I wasn't happy, so I walked away with dignity.

"Simon (Cowell) always ends up firing someone.

"I didn't want to give him the satisfaction. He always wants someone young and perky-t*tted sat next to him."

Despite ITV bosses previously asking for the telly dragon to return, she has ruled out any chance of a comeback.

Sharon said: "Simon wouldn't let them and I don't give a sh*t because I can go, f*ck you."

pages.subdeck: Sleeping on the job ... Maria O'Connor
pages.headline: Apprentice hopeful Maria gets a wake-up call
pages.teaser: BUSINESSWOMAN lets down her team in the latest episode by falling asleep during task
pages.articlebody:
APPRENTICE hopeful Maria O'Connor lets down her team in the latest episode  by falling asleep during the task.

In scenes set to be seen tonight, the restaurant owner nodded off in the back of the car while her teammates were busy deciding which gadget they should make and pitch to retailers.

The girls' team  called Sterling  picked Jane McEvoy as their leader, but struggled to choose their final product for the BBC1 show.

It was a choice between a tap cosy, which lets people put their feet up while in the tub, and a splash screen to put on the side of the bath for children.

Jane started to have doubts after meeting a mother and toddler focus group, telling the others: "Perhaps we're making our product very difficult. We have a bit of a dilemma here."

Meanwhile, things got heated with the boys' team, Phoenix, after they failed to agree on whether to produce a waste compactor bin or a pair of rubber gloves with scourers on one side.

Project manager Azhar Siddique seemed less than impressed, telling the boys: "I think people are just not committing to the product and I don't think they want to give 100 per cent to the product at all, or to winning the task."

  • The Apprentice is on BBC1 at 9pm tonight.
