pages.subdeck: Girls ... hunky Mullingar teen Niall is fighting them off
pages.headline: One Direction lads' fury at sex axe
pages.teaser: ONE Direction heart-throb Niall Horan is seething after being ordered off nookie by American record bosses
pages.articlebody:
ONE Direction heart-throb Niall Horan is seething after being ordered off nookie by American record bosses.

The boyband cutie had been set to put his Westmeath charm into overdrive in the US  with hordes of randy female fans ready to keep him Up All Night.

Instead, Mullingar lad Niall, 18, and his single bandmates have been banned from sex while they try to conquer the States.

Record execs, who are desperate to protect One Direction's clean-cut image, have handed the stars a strict set of rules to keep their rise to superstardom on course.

And the four singletons in the band  Niall, Harry Styles, Zayn Malik and Louis Tomlinson  have been ordered: No girlfriends and definitely no sex.

A source close to Niall revealed last night: "He's raging about it  all the lads are.

"Four of them are single and they've been told to stay that way as it appeals to their American teen fans. Niall is fighting off the women with his Irish accent and good looks so he's having to live like a monk."

Hunky bandmate Harry, 18, who split from Xtra Factor hottie Caroline Flack in January, is also fuming about 'no-romping' regime. Our source said: "He's come out of a relationship and wants to enjoy his freedom.

"But he's having to behave himself and keep the women at arm's length.

"They are all young lads and they have urges like anyone else their age.

"And the worst thing is the American girls are literally throwing themselves at them so there is so much temptation in their way."

Only singer Liam Payne has dodged the ban  because he's already dating sexy dancer Danielle Peazer.

The lads made history for a British/Irish band last week when their debut album Up All Night went straight to No1 in the US charts.

But the stars have been warned not to step out of line as the American market won't tolerate any slips in their squeaky clean image.

The source added: "Niall and the boys are being kept on a really tight leash and it is tough for them.

"But they are so determined to make it work in the States they'll do whatever they are told.

"Quite simply a sex scandal over there would be the end of the band."

irishsun@the-sun.ie

pages.subdeck: Bridging the gap ... Westway flyover looks the same today as it did in The Jam's 1977 cover
pages.headline: This is the more modern world
pages.teaser: AS plaque marks spot Bowie posed for 1972 album ... this is the more modern world
pages.byline: By TOM THOROGOOD and GRANT ROLLINGS
pages.articlebody:
A COMMEMORATIVE plaque was unveiled yesterday  in honour of Ziggy Stardust.

But although the tribute is intended to mark the spot where David Bowie posed for his classic 1972 album cover, the view  in central London's Heddon Street  looks very different today.

However, as our main picture shows, for music fans who prefer their rock landmarks set in stone  or concrete, even  the setting for the 1977 Jam LP This Is The Modern World is much more recognisable, even after 35 years.

Here we revisit some classic album cover locations to spot, in Mr Bowie's words, the ch-ch-ch-changes.

DAVID BOWIE, ZIGGY STARDUST: For his 1972 album Bowie was snapped outside a photographic studio in Heddon Street in central London  now it is a Moroccan restaurant, with tables and chairs on the pavement.

(Main image) THE JAM, THIS IS THE MODERN WORLD: The band  Paul Weller, Bruce Foxton and Rick Buckler  posed beneath the busy Westway flyover in West London for the cover shot for their second album in 1977.

During the 35 years since then the spot has gained an impressive sports centre.

But a tower block on the nearby Silchester Estate in the background looks just the same.

ARCTIC MONKEYS, FAVOURITE WORST NIGHTMARE: The band redecorated an empty council house in Leeming Close, Liverpool, for their 2007 album cover. A year later it was demolished to make way for new homes.

BLACK SABBATH, BLACK SABBATH: Ozzy Osbourne's band put disused Mapledurham mill, on the Thames near Reading, on their first album cover in 1970. In 1980 it was restored and is now a paying visitor attraction.

OASIS, (WHAT'S THE STORY) MORNING GLORY?: Some of the shops on Berwick Street in London's Soho have changed since the band made their ground-breaking second album in 1995.

But the record shop Sister Ray  named after the Velvet Underground song  is still there and the atmosphere feels the same.

PINK FLOYD, ANIMALS: In 1977, when the album was released, Battersea Power Station was still generating electricity.

Now the derelict building beside the Thames in London has lost its roof and is on English Heritage's Buildings At Risk register. And the band's flying pig, suspended between the chimneys, is no longer aloft.

THE ROLLING STONES, HOT ROCKS 1964-1971: The back of the 1971 LP shows the ruins of Swarkestone Pavilion.

The building in Derbyshire has since been renovated and turned into a one-bed holiday home.

THE STREETS, A GRAND DON'T COME FOR FREE: Singer Mike Skinner, who leaned on a Birmingham bus shelter for his 2004 album sleeve, has tweeted his disappointment that it has been replaced by a new one.

THE CLASH, THE CLASH: The band were photographed for their 1977 debut album in an alleyway outside the front door of their rehearsal space in Chalk Farm, north London. Now there's just a green bin.

image.caption: Bridging the gap ... Westway flyover looks the same today as it did in The Jam's 1977 cover

article.caption: Dry your eyes, Mike

pages.subdeck: Streetdance 2 ... George Sampson and Tom Conti
pages.headline: George Sampson wants to be lamped
pages.teaser: EXCLUSIVE: STREETDANCE 2 star on turning 18, being single and why he wants a lamppost tattoo on his back
pages.articlebody:
GEORGE Sampson is planning his first tattoo  as soon as he's bulked up.

The Streetdance 2 star wants an old-fashioned streetlamp, as a tribute to the Singing In The Rain routine which won him the 2008 series of Britain's Got Talent.

He said: "I'm waiting for me to put on a bit of weight. My metabolism at the moment is very high and when it slows down and I get a bit bigger, and I gain a bit of muscle, then I will get a tattoo.

"I think I want an old English lamppost up my back, but instead of a pole I want writing scribbled, but I don't know what it will be yet. As soon as I've figured it out I will get one.

"It comes from Singing in The Rain  and my friend told me this really good quote: 'It's not about waiting for the storm to pass, it's about learning to dance in the rain.'"

Although he turned 18 while filming the Streetdance sequel, he tells The Sun he still has to get his mum's approval over the design.

He said: "My mum has been very fussy about this thing because I've been talking for ages about getting one but she says, 'Until you know what you want and you're happy with it, really happy with it, you're not getting one.'"

In Streetdance 2, George goes from the background to the spotlight as returning character Eddie.

Together with fellow streetdancer Ash (Falk Hentshel) he gathers the best dancers from around the world in an attempt to beat top streetdance crew Invincible.

Their plans take a new twist when they discover hot Latin dancer Eva, played by Sofia Boutella, and try for a new dance fusion.

Manchester lad George, who also stars in Waterloo Road, turned 18 on the shoot in Berlin.

But the celebrations weren't as epic as he'd hoped.

He explained: "At the start of it they told me that they weren't shooting the day after my birthday, so I thought, 'Ok, so that's a really good opportunity to get drunk on my 18th birthday.'

"Then we were shooting the day after my birthday and I was in the first scene in the morning so we didn't really drink too much.

"I had kept it kind of quiet but the whole cast, the producers, the choreographers and the crew all came out, we had a nice big meal and a couple of nice drinks afterwards. It was overwhelming."

The movie reunited George with fellow BGT contestants Flawless and Got To Dance winner Akai.

And Tom Conti joins the cast as Eva's protective uncle Manu.

Streetdance 2 3D is released nationwide on March 30.

video.caption: STREETDANCE 2 star George on girls, booze and why he wants a lamppost tattoo

It shouldn't take long to mould Mickey into a rugby player. Pulling moonies inside a team bus isn't hard.

pages.headline: Marilyn's secret sets appeal
pages.teaser: MARILYN Monroe oozes sex appeal in new rare photos  including naked calendar shot
pages.articlebody:
MARILYN Monroe oozes sex appeal in previously unseen photos  taken by her make-up artist to help her relax on a film set.

Allan "Whitey" Snyder grabbed his camera when the actress was 27 and suffering from nerves while shooting her first major role, in the 1953 movie Niagara.

A trusted pal, he often took snaps to ease her stage fright.

Now his amazing archive  including a rare naked calendar shot of Marilyn  is set to fetch thousands at a sale in Beverly Hills on Saturday.

Auctioneer Darren Julien said: "Whitey was her make- up artist for 16 years.

"Sometimes she'd get nervous and he would photograph her and she'd come to life. It took her mind off her problems."

Whitey was a pallbearer at Marilyn's funeral in 1962. He died aged 79 in 1994.

Mr Julien added: "These come from his estate. They've never been seen before."

image.caption: Hollywood legend Marilyn Monroe ... unseen photos

pages.subdeck: Humiliated ... Debbie Clements' ex posted a sex tape of her to an online escort site
pages.headline: Ex posted sex tape like Tulisa's on net
pages.teaser: X FACTOR judge's humiliation stirs bad memories for mum
pages.articlebody:
WHEN Debbie Clements read about X Factor judge Tulisa's internet sex video humiliation, it instantly brought back chilling memories.

Tulisa's nightmare  film of an "intimate" moment with former boyfriend Justin Edwards suddenly appearing online  had mum-of-one Debbie reliving her own experiences of ten years ago.

Now 29, she was filmed romping with an ex  who then posted videos and pictures on an escort site when they split.

The horrified teenager asked a solicitor to help her get the video taken off the web  but was told there was nothing she could do because the tape was her ex's property.

The clip was still live on the net a year ago when her partner of six years, Dave Bond, found it and walked out on her.

Debbie, a cleaner from Blackburn, says: "Seeing my video online made me feel sick. I just cried and cried.

"It makes me worry that one day my little boy might see it and be ashamed of me.

"I feel so sorry for Tulisa. Doesn't the person leaking it realise doing things like this causes heartache and despair?"

When Debbie was 19 she met a man called Andy who was ten years older than her.

She says: "He was very confident and very sure of himself. He didn't really have any inhibitions whereas I did, so I kind of looked up to him.

"We had a sexual relationship. It was good but he was quite experimental in the bedroom.

"I'd let him take naked pictures and films as I just saw it as something that turned him on.

"He filmed me about half a dozen times that I knew of and about two or three times where I was unaware the camera was on.

"It was all on a hand-held camera. Sometimes he held it, other times he mounted it on a tripod.

"Sex played quite a big part but he took me out for meals and we went drinking. We were a normal couple, apart from there was a bit more sex than usual.

"Over time he became a little bit too overbearing and dominant.

"He wanted me to do things I wasn't comfortable doing and go to places I didn't want to go, like swingers clubs. That's when I called it a day.

"We were together for about five months. I chatted with him on the phone after the split and then after a few weeks I heard nothing from him."

A few months later Debbie checked her emails and there was one from a man trying to book an escort.

She says: "I sent him an email telling him he had the wrong address and never to email me again.

"He was adamant it was the right address and replied saying, 'Is this Raquel?'

"He gave me the name of an agency that he'd booked "Raquel" through.

"I found the website and under the name Raquel were photos and videos my ex had taken  of me.

"It's hard to describe that moment  it was like a shot of ice had run through my body.

"I went into shock and began to cry. It was horrible knowing my most intimate moments, shared with my then boyfriend, were on the internet for everyone to see.

"People only had to go on the internet to see them and it made me feel sick.

"There was nobody I felt I could tell at the time. I was only a teenager and felt really embarrassed. I told a couple of my closest girlfriends who I could trust about this but only years later.

"I kept it a secret for the rest of the time because I felt ashamed.

"I felt so vulnerable and paranoid. I didn't know if friends or boys I knew had seen it.

"I've since realised I had nothing to be ashamed of. He should be the one hanging his head in shame for doing what he did."

Debbie got in touch with a solicitor but there was nothing he could do.

She adds: "He told me he was powerless to help because the tapes and photographs are the ex's personal property and if he wants to put them on the internet, he can.

"I was devastated. When I phoned Andy I couldn't get through, and on the three occasions I went round to his house there was no answer.

"I pushed a note through his letterbox begging him to take the pictures and videos down but I got no reply. Eventually, he moved  but I don't know where.

"In the end I had to accept there was nothing I could do and I got on with my life.

"I presumed they'd eventually get lost in the internet or the site would be taken down. Over time I forgot about them."

Two years later when Debbie met Dave, she thought the horror was behind her. After six years together, she gave birth to their son and life was complete.

But a year ago Debbie's nightmare came back to haunt her.

She says: "Dave came home in a foul mood. He'd been out with his pals having a few drinks and told me everyone had been talking about me. I joked that I hoped it was all good but he wasn't laughing.

"He picked up our iPad and found the escort site. I recognised it instantly and my heart jumped. My pictures were underneath the name of an escort.

"He looked me in the eye and asked, 'So you've been escorting on the side?'

"I sobbed that I hadn't but before I could carry on he said, 'One of the lads down the pub found this. They were all ogling your pictures. One of them joked he was going to book you 'til I threatened to knock him out.'

"I tried to explain it wasn't true and it was an ex who had put them there  but Dave was not having any of it. He announced he was moving out.

"I watched him walk out of the door and it was as though I was in a bad dream.

"I sent him text after text pleading for him to come home for the sake of me and our little boy, but he ignored them."

A few days later Dave phoned to tell Debbie he was leaving her for good.

She says: "Hearing that he couldn't forgive me made my mood change from despair to anger. When he came for his things I didn't speak to him or look at him.

"We're friendly and amicable because of our little boy but there's no chance of reconciliation."

She adds: "When I saw this had happened to Tulisa it brought it all back to me again.

"These tapes wreck relationships, cause family problems and all sorts of stress. I wish laws would be introduced to stop this."

Meanwhile, unrepentant Dave says: "It was too much to think my mates were looking at explicit pictures of my girlfriend in the pub.

"I just couldn't look her in the face after that. Maybe she wasn't an escort. I'll have to take her word for that.

"But it doesn't alter the fact that those pictures are up there for everyone to see."

myView



By DEIDRE SANDERS, Sun Agony Aunt

LOTS of readers write to me having been caught out in just the same way as Tulisa and Debbie.

They have let their partner take revealing photos or videos of them  only to have them appear on the internet where friends and family can stumble across them.

It's a grey area of the law. In theory it can be an offence under the Obscene Publications Act to post sexual images on the net  but only if they are of a very extreme nature.

It is also an offence "to operate equipment with the intention of enabling another person to observe, for the purpose of obtaining sexual gratification, a third person doing a private act, knowing the person being filmed did not consent to that purpose".

You can complain to the website provider and to the police  though the sites often turn out to be hosted outside the UK and so outside Britain's jurisdiction.

In any case, as Debbie found, it can be difficult to convince a new partner you didn't give consent, let alone a court of law.

The best advice has to be: Don't ever let anyone take  or send anyone  photos or videos of yourself you wouldn't be happy for your mum, friends or an employer to see.

Additional reporting: PAUL CARTER

pages.subdeck: Busker to beauty queen ... Miss England contestant Lena Walker
pages.headline: From busker to beauty queen
pages.teaser: ENCOURAGEMENT from passers-by led to teenager entering beauty pageant
pages.articlebody:
A STUNNING busker has turned Miss England hopeful after her fans encouraged her to enter the beauty pageant.

Lena Walker took to the streets of her home city of Leicester with her guitar to raise money for charity.

But the 17-year-old was surprised when scores of people approached her to praise her music  and her good looks.

The pretty student said: "I decided to give busking a go  but never expected the reaction I got.

"Loads of people were coming up to me and commenting on my music, but also my looks."

After entering the Miss England contest, she battled through several rounds to make the national finals.

She added: "I've always been a down-to-earth girl, so had never really considered putting myself in to be judged on my looks.

"But after my family and friends said I should do it, and with the confidence of all the comments from the public, I thought why not."

And after beating off competition from 22 other girls, she will now compete in the Miss England final in Leicester on June 26.

Lena said: "I don't think it has really hit me that I've made it into the last 60 girls left from the whole UK.

"I'm sure it will sink in once I'm on that stage."

And she says she's looking forward to competing in front of her home crowd.

She said: "Hopefully my down-to-earth nature will shine through and win me some support.

"I'll have plenty of family and friends there, what with it being held in my home town.

"It could be a struggle fitting them all in!"

If things don't work out, Lena may still have a career in music  as she raised a whopping £35 an hour while busking

But the big-hearted student donated the cash she raised to charities.

She added: "The public have been very generous whenever I have put myself on a limb and taken to the streets to play my music.

"I play a lot of my own stuff that I write, but also play a few crowd-pleasers like David Guetta, Jessie J and Foster The People.

"On a good day I've made £35 an hour and would stay for a couple of hours at least.

"It isn't all glamour though. I'd often get back from a session busking and your fingers would be numb thanks to the cold."

article.caption: Afghan refugee's Miss England bid
Miss Asia UK: I went from tomboy to beauty queen
Amy Jackson is Britain's Bollywood babe

pages.subdeck: Barred ... transgender model Jenna Talackova, right
pages.headline: Aspiring Miss Universe axed for being born a man
pages.teaser: TRANSGENDER model Jenna Talackova axed after show chiefs discover she was a man
pages.articlebody:
A MISS Universe hopeful has been booted out after pageant bosses discovered she used to be a MAN.

Transgender model Jenna Talackova, 23, was barred from the Canadian round of the contest and is claiming discrimination.

National director Denis Davila said only girls "naturally born female" were allowed, adding: "We embrace diversity. Just because she can't compete doesn't mean we stopped loving her."

Her exit sparked a wave of support with more than 25,000 people signing an online petition calling for her reinstatement.

Talackova vowed to fight the move, made only after she made it to the finals of Miss Vancouver.

She first considered herself female aged four and began hormone therapy at 14. At 19 she went under the knife and had gender reassignment to complete her transformation.

She said: "I will look to turn this situation into a positive so that other people in a similar situation are not discriminated against in the future."

Contest chiefs issued a statement saying she was eliminated "because she did not meet the requirements to compete despite having stated otherwise on her entry form".

Davila maintained every contestant must be a "naturally born female" and Talackova had been "dishonest".

He said: "There is no discrimination here at all. We have a set of rules that we must enforce.

"The rules are very clear and there's no way we can go back on it."

article.caption: Angolan beauty is Miss Universe

image.caption: Barred ... transgender model Jenna Talackova, right

pages.subdeck: 'My photo journey reminds me how hard I worked' ... Nicola Williams
pages.headline: 11st weightloss picture diary
pages.teaser: TEACHER shares snaps she took every month until she reached her goal...a size 12
pages.articlebody:
WHEN primary school teacher Nicola Williams decided to lose weight, she looked to herself for inspiration.

She decided to take a self-portrait every month to clearly see her progress and motivate her to continue.

Her inspiring photo casebook charts her epic FOUR-YEAR weight loss  from 24 stone and a size 32 to the 13 stone size 12 she is today.

Her incredible photo diary helped her jack in the junk food and bin the bad habits in pursuit of a healthier, happier life.

Now, looking back through the pictures proves incredibly emotional for Nicola, 39.

She says: "When I show people they stare open-mouthed as I flick through the album and shrink before their eyes.

I can't believe how big I was and how much I've transformed. It's incredible and I love the new improved me.

"My photo journey reminds me of how hard I worked to get where I am today and I hope it inspires other women to begin their own journey."

At the age of 24, Nicola was 16 stone and by the time she was 34 she weighed 24st.

She recalls: "I worried if I was going to fit through a small gap or get stuck on a small chair. So I'd try to avoid putting myself in potentially embarrassing situations.

"For breakfast, I'd have four slices of toast. For lunch I'd make a sandwich with four slices of white bread with double the filling.

"Dinners were always whatever was quick. Pasta bakes, pizzas and takeaways were my regular meals of choice.

"My biggest weakness though, were crisps. I'd never go a day without eating at least three bags.

"Working as a primary school teacher, the staff room is always full of cakes and chocolates to snack on during break times."

Nicola, of Llanelli, Wales, was eating around 4,900 calories a day, 2,900 above the recommended intake. And it affected her confidence.

She says: "Trying to run around with the kids during PE lessons and teaching them about healthy lifestyles was always difficult as I felt like a hypocrite."

She also struggled to find clothes to flatter her huge frame. She continues: "I had to settle for T-shirts that managed to cover my enormous body and trousers that didn't dig in to my sides.

"The only things that looked good were shoes. I loved being able to walk into High Street shops and pick out a pair of pretty high heels, slip them on my feet and feel sexy.

"So I went crazy for them. Platforms, stilettos, boots, wedges  you name them, I had a pair. In every colour and for every occasion I had shoes that made me feel great.

"Worth more than £3,500, I had just over 100 pairs in my collection before my life changed."

Then, in December 2007, Nicola joined a weekly slimming class  purely to keep a friend company.

She says: "I swapped white bread for brown, reduced my portion sizes and snacked on fruit and veg. I found it surprisingly refreshing to come out of my normal convenience eating routine and try something new."

Within a month, Nicola had shed 10lb. Yet she struggled to see a difference in her appearance.

"So my friend suggested taking a picture to show me how well I'd done. It was the motivation I needed to carry on," she says.

"Comparing myself month by month stunned me. My face was thinner and I could notice the difference in my waistline and arms.

"I began looking forward to each month when the time came to take a picture and compare myself to the previous one."

Nicola also joined a gym and began working out twice a week.

She says: "After the first year I'd lost five stone  down from 24st to 19st.

"My meals changed completely to consist of a piece of toast for breakfast, a sandwich with two pieces of brown bread for lunch, fruit for a snack and meat with vegetables for dinner.

"Looking at myself filled me with pride and the compliments I was receiving from friends and family were incredible.

"I was determined this wasn't going to just be a fad diet phase  this was a new lifestyle for me."

In the next three years she lost a further six stone, dropping to 13st 2lb.

Nicola says: "Every woman wants to look their best in a photo.

"If I was ever tempted to have a take-away binge at the end of the month, I'd think about having my picture taken and it would put me off."

And for shoe-mad Nicola there was only one way to mark her sensational new figure.

"In January this year I splashed out on a beautiful pair of £380 cream Jimmy Choo shoes to celebrate."

article.caption: Why we're all tee totally happy
My 8-year takeaway binge cost £25k...and my unborn baby's life
'I'm proud to be UK average size 16. And I'll never yo-yo again'
You wouldn't eat 13 teaspoons of sugar in one go... so why drink it?

pages.subdeck: Quirky ... Jessie J
pages.headline: What your clothes say about YOU
pages.teaser: BEHAVIOUR expert Dr Pam Spurr analyses six celebrities and reveals what their fashion tells us about their personality
pages.articlebody:
MOST of us flash more flesh as the weather warms up but we may not realise what our outfits reveal about our personality.

A new book by US psychologist Dr Jennifer Baumgartner, You Are What You Wear: What Your Clothes Reveal About You, claims to unwrap the secrets behind our choice of outfits.

Here behaviour expert Dr Pam Spurr analyses six celebrities and reveals what their style says about them.

Jessie J



Style: The singer's outlandish styles show she likes to do things her own way.

Style secret: Eccentric dressers may seem extrovert but are often shy deep down. Their clothes may act as armour, diverting attention from them.

Cameron Diaz

Style: The film star's relaxed look indicates a more carefree and grounded personality.

Style secret: When someone feels they are seen chiefly as a sex object, they may downplay their feminine side to show there is more to their character.

Kate, Duchess of Cambridge

Style: As a younger Royal, Kate could push the boat out more with her outfits but plays it safe.

Style secret: Kate probably likes to maintain routine and please others. But some conservative dressers may long to break free.

Christina Hendricks

Style: The vampish Mad Men actress can seem aloof and untouchable.

Style secret: Someone who dresses like this may not feel sexy inside. She might be over-compensating to cover insecurity.

Beyonce

Style: The singer's trademark jewellery reveals a powerful personality who is happy to show she is on top.

Style secret: Lots of flash or expensive gear can mask a deeper insecurity that makes the wearer feel a need to prove themself.

Holly Willoughby

Style: Holly's style is feminine and traditional, but with a twist of sexiness.

Style secret: The girl next door may secretly wish to be more assertive and outgoing. Often more complicated than she appears.

pages.subdeck: Incredible figure ... mum-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman
pages.headline: 'Octomom' poses for topless snaps
pages.teaser: MUM-OF-FOURTEEN poses for topless snaps three years after having her octuplets
pages.articlebody:
MUM-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman shows off her incredible post-babies body in these revealing snaps.

Nadya, dubbed "Octomom" after giving birth to octuplets in 2009, happily posed topless for a magazine shoot.

And while she boasts of attracting plenty of admirers with her flat stomach and 34DD boobs, she claims she has been celibate for 13 years  as her children were all conceived through a sperm donor.

She explained: "I get way too much male attention, but I won't date until the octuplets are 18  I live for them now.

"I know a lot of women like male attention, but I'll go out with no make-up on and wear tracksuits, a wig and even a fake pregnancy stomach to put them off."

She added: "I wouldn't rule out a relationship in the future. But now, when men look at me, I look away and they know not to approach me.

"I know I'm beautiful  I don't need a man to tell me that."

Nadya, who lives in California, US, already had six kids  Elijah, now 10, Amerah, nine, Joshua, eight, Aiden, six, and twins Caleb and Calyssa, five, when she claims she decided to have more embryos implanted from the same sperm donor.

And her brood was soon joined by six boys and two girls  Noah, Jonah, Jeremiah, Isiah, Josiah, McCai, Maliah and Nariah, who turned three in January this year.

But amazingly, the 36-year-old says it was no effort at all to get her figure back following her last pregnancy.

She explained: "I just pinged back into shape like a rubber band after the kids  I don't know how I did it.

"I eat like a horse, don't count calories and have never owned a set of scales.

"I gained an entire human when I was pregnant with the octuplets  going from 10st to over 19st  but, two months later, I was a size eight again. Now, I never weigh myself."

  • The full feature appears in this month's Closer magazine, on sale now.

image.caption: Incredible figure ... mum-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman

pages.subdeck: Nearly new ... the Duchess in grey Jesire coat dress
pages.headline: Look Kate for less
pages.teaser: CUT-PRICE Kate is at it again  but this time the queen of high-street style has been hitting the thrift shops
pages.articlebody:
CUT-price Kate is at it again  but this time the High Street style queen has been hitting the thrift shops.

Last week it was revealed the Duchess sent aides to a second-hand dress agency just a few miles from her Berkshire family home to find her outfits.

Her nearly new purchases from The Stock Exchange, in Sunninghill, include the grey Jesire coat dress she wore to a National Portrait Gallery event last month.

Described as a "premier venue for the fashion-conscious bargain hunter", the shop sells unwanted designer gear for clients and takes a 50 per cent cut of the sale price.

We sent Sun stylist Nana Acheampong to the shop to put together a wardrobe that was fit for a princess.

She found top High Streets labels including Kate's favourites LK Bennett and Karen Millen, plus fashion house labels including Chloe.

Nana, 25, said: "Staff revealed the store takes donations from a host of local TV presenters. They get a cut of any sales but anything not sold after five weeks goes to charity.

"They haven't seen the Duchess in the store but they were really excited when they saw Kate on TV wearing the Jesire dress.

"It looks like the Duchess has a secret shopper and The Stock Exchange are keen for whoever it is to continue shopping there."

Nana managed to put together four outfits for less than £180.

Here, Kate lookalike Chelsea Collins, 22, from Poole, Dorset, models our princess perfect looks.

pages.subdeck: Shine on ... glossy skin is season's must-have
pages.headline: Go with the glow
pages.teaser: FORGET heavy tans and thick layers of foundation  radiance is the key word on the catwalk
pages.articlebody:
THIS is the season to embrace dewy skin. Forget heavy tans, thick layers of foundation and cakey bronzer  radiance is now the key word in the beauty world.

Catwalk models have all been given little else but radiant, glowing skin, while celebrities such as Natalie Portman are setting the precedent for softer, fresher looks.

If YOU fancy brightening your complexion, a few simple tricks can lift your skin.

LAUREN NAYLOR shares her skin secrets so you can get up and glow.

Skin perfection



LET'S face it, we'd all love to feel confident make-up free and be blessed with a radiant, glowy complexion.

But daily exposure to harsh elements can make it difficult to pull off. Look out for nourishing and calming skincare ingredients to give your skin radiance and combat dryness and redness.

Head therapist Sherelle at celebrity skin care spa Linda Meredith, whose clients include Kate Beckinsale and Gwyneth Paltrow, says: "Start by using a cleanser packed full of naturally occurring vitamins, omega oils and amino acids.

"We are exposed to various chemicals throughout our day so look for paraben-free formulas.

"Take a generous amount of cleansing product mixed with warm water and with a feather-soft touch gently massage the product in with your fingertips.

"By massaging softly you are pushing the product into your skin rather than moving facial muscles about aggressively.

And the warm water heats the skin for the products to penetrate deeper. When you rinse, use a soft sponge, gentle cotton wool pads or your hands  flannels are too abrasive.

"An old-school, tried-and-tested method that we use is to give your skin a deep steam once a week over the basin. This will help open up and deep-clean any clogged pores.

"There is nothing wrong with squeezing out blackheads  just make sure you take a thick piece of tissue and use the sides of your fingertips to push them out.

"Only do this for three to five minutes max. If they won't come, they're not ready, and if you use your fingernails you will break and damage your skin."

We love REN Hydra-Calm Cleansing Milk with peroxidase enzymes from fennel seed extract to protect distressed skin and Omega 3 and 7 essential fatty acids to reduce inflammation, £18.

Linda Meredith Paraben-free Cream Cleanser with avocado and citrus fruit oils, £39 (stockists, 020 7225 2755). Team with a brightening moisturiser such as Simple Radiance Brightening Moisturiser, £6.99 (Boots).

Pep up



IF your complexion is looking lacklustre, it's likely you need to exfoliate sluggish skin cells. Look for natural ingredients that gently slough off dead skin.

Walnut shell, papaya and pineapple are all fantastic natural exfoliators. Try Origins Never A Dull Moment skin-brightening polisher with fruit extracts to help reveal a healthy glow, £24 (Origins).

Put your feet up and slather on Elemis Papaya Enzyme Peel, £28.60 (Elemis counters). We love the intoxicating Victoria sponge-like scent.

Make me up



SKIN highlighters add radiance in an instant. You can layer under make-up or wear stand-alone.

If you are going out and want to appear more made up, try adding highlighter along the cheekbones, down the bridge of the nose and on the forehead  this gives a shimmering dewiness.

You can also place highlighter on the brow bone and under the arch of the brow to make your eyes appear brighter.

L'Oreal Lumi Magique Concealer, £8.49, (Boots) will help to brighten the eyes if you dab a small amount in the darkest areas, ie, underneath, and Bobbi Brown Creamy Concealer in Chestnut, £17, is great for darker skins. Gorgeously rich and luxurious, MAC's Strobe Cream is used by many of the world's high-profile make-up artists.

Wear it under or over make-up for a dewy, almost wet-look effect and team with MAC's Lustre Drops in Sun Rush, £17.50, for a pop of warmth.

Last but not least, finish your face with a burst of brightening blusher on the apples of your cheeks such as Gosh Natural Blush in Electric Pink, Max Factor Miracle Touch Creamy Blush in Soft Pink, £6.99, or Maybelline NY Dream Soft Blush in Peach 02, £4.49 (all Superdrug).

pages.subdeck: Risky business ... new warning highlights danger of unqualified beauty therapists
pages.headline: Truth about rogue beauticians...
pages.teaser: THOUSANDS of women are putting themselves at risk by inviting rogue beauty therapists into their homes
pages.articlebody:
THOUSANDS of women are putting themselves at risk by inviting rogue beauty therapists into their homes.

Some agencies, such as online beauty therapist directory mobilebeauty.uk.com, allow anyone to register and advertise for work with NO checks.

Lauren Shalson, co-founder and director of reputable company Spa By Car, says: "Many online beauty agencies offer work or let therapists register based simply on a phone call. How can you safely send someone into a client's home without at least meeting them in person?

"After a thorough interview process, to be accepted on to our books our therapists need a minimum of NVQ level 2 and 3 and arrive in branded clothing, a branded car and bring proof of certificates to the appointment.

"We, as clients, need to be fully aware we could be letting anyone into our home and of the danger we could be placing ourselves in, especially if opting for a specialist treatment like intimate waxing. The mobile beauty sector is enjoying a surge because clients want therapies in the safety of their own home.

"Yet unscrupulous operators are sending unvetted, unqualified and uninsured therapists to clients' homes  exposing them to unimaginable risks. If you are using a mobile beauty therapist I would ask for references. If you are to use one at all I would use one that has been recommended to you and who has proved they can do a good job.

"I would ask who their insurance provider is and for proof of training  especially if you are going for eyelash extensions, where sharp tweezers are used which could cause a lot of damage in the hands of the wrong person. Be warned!"

article.caption: I was terrified my PIP implants were a ticking timebomb. I just wanted them out
I spent £10,000 to look like one of my Barbies

pages.subdeck: Different perspective ... Renee Zellweger says that she feels lucky to have European parents
pages.headline: Renee's European parents
pages.teaser: ACTRESS Renee Zellweger reveals how her Norwegian mother influenced her career
pages.articlebody:
RENEE ZELLWEGER became a star thanks to her role opposite Tom Cruise in 1996 hit movie Jerry Maguire.

She is now established as one of the best-known and most highly paid actresses in Hollywood.

She won an Oscar for her role in the drama Cold Mountain and is famous for two films playing Bridget Jones.

Renee, 42, who had a short-lived marriage to singer Kenny Chesney in 2005, lives alone.

Here, she tells GARTH PEARCE about the influence her Norwegian-born mum Kjellfrid has had on her.

I DIDN'T grow up in a house where Mum focused on appearances. I don't remember her ever saying, "Wouldn't you be pretty if you did this or that?"

She never focused on anything beyond wanting me to be presentable  just well-groomed.

She wanted me to take care of myself and be healthy.

She did ask one or two questions when I became a cheerleader at high school because I would be teasing my hair and wearing lipstick and eyeliner.

I have an affiliation with a lot of countries. My mum was from Norway, my dad from Switzerland and my grandmother was Finnish, I have an Italian uncle, my first love was from South Africa and I was born in Texas.

I am definitely a Texan girl. It is a culture you really love in a Latin sort of way. You taste it and hear it and the climate is hot  Texas hot.

I felt lucky that my parents were European  different  and opened the doors to let me see America is not the centre of the universe.

It meant that, with Bridget Jones, I could go to London and enjoy all things English that make the country so wonderful.

During the making of the first film, I was even whistling songs by the Spice Girls.

But my mum was a realist about bringing up a teenage girl in America and kept a sense of humour.

She taught me that there are consequences for the things you say and do. She wanted me to grow up to be a good person. She and Dad liked simple and quiet. We had a very quiet house.

My mum didn't talk about her childhood growing up in Norway during the Second World War. Her sisters talked but all had difficulty in putting into words what they had seen.

They told about women giving birth in tunnels because there was no safe haven in any other structure.

And about being lost from family members and not being sure if they were alive.

So it was different for me, from my friends, growing up in a house where your mother was grateful just to have peace.

There was one thing which was never acceptable, though.

When I said: "I don't know how to do that", she would say: "Learn."

She encouraged me to get a college education (Renee has an English degree) as something to fall back on if acting didn't work out.

I moved to Los Angeles on December 6, 1993, to be exact.

My attitude was that I was going to see where it took me.

I had been working in Texas from the age of 21, and been in a couple of films. But I had pretty well exhausted my learning opportunities.

So I took a grungy little one-bed apartment and was scared to death of the future. It was a leap of faith, I guess.

I had some friends in LA who I had met on films but inside and emotionally, I felt alone.

To make a living, I worked in a bar called The Three Cubs on a street called Vine, behind the Mobil gas station.

It was an incredible place for a girl like me, who had lived in relatively safe places all her life.

There were crack deals being done on the street corners  so I would come back from the bar late at night then not be able to get out of my car to my apartment until the deals were completed.

I worked at the bar for two years. That was why Mum's guidance was so important and I stayed happy.

When you can take care of yourself and see your friends, that is all that matters.

The main difference that the film Jerry Maguire made in my life was I could pay my rent and didn't have to waitress any more. It gave me freedom.

I knew from the start that if I failed in acting, I always had my degree and could try a million things. I was not a "look at me" kind of girl.

I had gravitated toward acting because I had a vivid imagination and daydreamed a lot.

But I did not daydream about being on a film set, winning an Oscar or having people know my name.

I am grateful for the fact my mum never worried that I would compromise myself.

She was always telling me, 'You don't sit down enough'  but she learned to trust my instincts.

article.caption: Jerry Maguire actor's grown up to be a big star

image.caption: Different perspective ... Renee Zellweger says that she feels lucky to have European parents

pages.subdeck: Curvy ... Steps star Claire Richards
pages.headline: Richards: I'm proud to be size 16
pages.teaser: STEPS star Claire Richards on why she will never starve herself to be skinny again
pages.articlebody:
STEPS star Claire Richards has vowed to stop her yo-yo dieting  and reckons at size 16 she has never been happier.

In an interview with The Sun she hit back at her latest critics, who have claimed she is too fat for the dance routines in the band's comeback shows.

Claire, 34, revealed that her famous weight problems started back in the Nineties, when she was a svelte size 10 and trying out for the band.

She said: "At the audition I was told to lose weight if I wanted to be in Steps, so I did. That set me on the road of starvation for a few years."

Now the singer, whose 22-date comeback tour with Steps starts on April 2, refuses to bow to that sort of pressure.

She said: "I have spent so many years starving myself to be skinny. You can damage yourself by doing that  and I probably have in some ways.

"I think it's really sad that there is so much emphasis on a woman's size, certainly in the music industry.

"It's not really fair, and it doesn't make your average woman feel that great about herself. It makes you feel low.

"You are being told by magazines that you shouldn't look like that, you should be skinny  and that's just not the way it is.

"Being a size 16 doesn't mean you don't look good.

"You are brainwashed into thinking you can't wear nice clothes because you are a little bigger and you have to wear baggy stuff to hide whatever's going on underneath  and it's rubbish.

"I'm a size 14 to 16 and I have a waist, I have boobs and I have a bum. I can accentuate those assets and still wear a nice dress and feel good about myself.

"It is important to remember that a size 16 is the average size of a woman in the UK. It is odd how these women are made to feel like they are not the norm but they are."

At the height of her fame with Steps Claire starved herself to a size eight before becoming a size 20 when the band split in 2001. Her weight has fluctuated ever since.

She said of the latest criticism: "The stories circulating about me struggling with dance moves are complete rubbish.

"I don't know where that has come from. Maybe someone has thought, 'Oh, she's bigger than the others so she must be struggling'. It's not an issue. It is just one of those things. People have just got to be nasty sometimes.

"I am putting in as much work and effort as everybody else.

"It is tough  it's a two-hour show, dancing for pretty much the whole thing. Just because I am a bigger size, I am no less fit than anybody else. It's cr*p.

"You can run every day and be fit and then be put in the situation that we are all in and you are using muscles you didn't even know you had.

"It's not as simple as someone being fit and someone not being fit  or someone being a size 16 and someone being a size 8.

"It's all going well. I don't know if it's because I'm a bit older now but I seem to be much more focused and picking up choreography better than I ever did.

"I'm not a trained dancer so that was always something I struggled with. Now we are just making sure it all looks perfect. I am in the middle of rehearsals at the moment, so it is a bit manic but really good."

Claire admits the interest in her size is something she has got used to.

She said: "The obsession with my size gets on my nerves a lot less now than it used to. I am happy with the way I am."

Claire lives in Middlesex with her hubby Reece, 43, an electrician and their children, Charlie, four, and two-year-old Daisy.

She added: "My husband loves me, my kids love me and nobody I am working with thinks it's an issue. If I look out into that audience when I'm up on stage with Steps, at least there will be women out there just like me who will feel a bit better about themselves because I am not a size 8.

"I am not trying to make a stand about my figure  but I've been a size 8 and I was miserable. I probably could have gone down to that size again  but what's the point if you are not going to be that for ever?

"I don't want to be yo-yoing any more  and if that means I'll just be a bit bigger, that's just the way it's got to be.

"It's not like I am starting out now. Steps wouldn't be the same if I wasn't in it, so they can't say to me now, 'You have to lose weight otherwise you can't be in the group'.

"There is no way anyone could tell me I'm too big or I have to lose weight now  because they can't do the tour without me.

"As a group, we always said if one of us didn't want to do it, then it wouldn't happen. They are certainly not going to kick me out for being a size 16."

Claire is also hosting Lorraine's Cake Club, a search on Sun columnist Lorraine Kelly's ITV show to find Britain's best cake.

And the singer reckons most online comments and tweets about her are supportive.

She said: "I would say that 95 per cent of people are saying, 'I think she looks great'.

"From doing the TV show Slave To Food last year about the kind of trouble I have had to deal with about my weight, I was surprised by the response I got.

"I had people saying, 'Thank you, you are so brave for doing that show. I can now look at a person on telly and say that she is just like me'.

"Many women have said to me, 'Hearing you talk about this stuff is like looking in the mirror.'

"There aren't many of us out there who will be honest and say, 'I struggle with my weight'.

"I don't really want to struggle any more, so this is me  and if you don't like it, tough."

n.watkins@the-sun.co.uk



Claire's changing body



1999  size 8, 8st 7Ib



2005  size 16, 13st



2008  size 18, 15st



2008  size 10, 10st 7Ib



2009  size 18, 15st



2011  size 14-16, 12st

image.caption: Curvy ... Steps star Claire Richards

pages.subdeck: A Mother's Day wish ... Louise Redknapp with her son
pages.headline: Louise's Mother's Day message
pages.teaser: LOUISE Redknapp talks about her love for her mother and UNICEF
pages.articlebody:
LOUISE Redknapp is no stranger to what it takes to be a mum, with two young sons to look after as well as juggling a busy schedule.

And the TV presenter has been looking forward to spending some quality time with her own mother as well as her children this Mother's Day.

However the 37-year-old is also keen to raise awareness of those families who won't enjoy such a relaxing time on Sunday.

The star has previously spent time meeting both mums and children in East Africa where she was shocked at what she saw.

Here Louise speaks about her experiences, the work being done by humanitarian aid charity UNICEF and how you can help.

"I cherish my relationship with my mum, she's my rock in so many aspects of my life. I treat her as often as I can and when Mother's Day comes around I try and do something a little extra special.

"This coming Mother's Day I know that my two boys will wake me up with breakfast in bed, it's usually burnt toast and a luke warm cup of tea, and it will be the best breakfast I'll have all year!

"I know we'll have a lovely family day but for many mothers around the world they won't be comforted by those certainties, they have no idea how their day will begin or how it will end.

"I'll be thinking of these mums this Mothers Day who'll be fighting to save their child's life, desperately trying to find enough food so that their child can survive Mother's Day, and then the next day and every day after that.

"I'm sure you've seen in the news, as I have, that more than a million children across both East and West Africa are at risk of dying over the coming months if they do not receive more help soon.

"UNICEF, the world's leading children's organisation, is already there with local partners to try and help children and their families before its too late, but they urgently need more funds to be able to do this.

"As a mum, all you want to do is protect and provide for your family, I can't begin to feel how desperate, frustrated and anxious these mums must be all the time without any food to feed their children.

"I have travelled to East Africa and I found the sight of malnourished children heartbreaking. I talked to some of these kids and was shocked to hear how little they ate on a daily basis.

"I find it almost impossible to imagine that with a supermarket on every corner and all the food I could want, that around the world every hour, 300 children are still dying from hunger.

"Just think, by the time you've read this paper, had a cup of tea and phoned your mum, another 300 children will have died, just because they don't have enough to eat.

"This Mother's Day, it's not about feeling guilty for what you've got, or feeling like you can't be spoilt. Of course you can. It's just about taking a moment to remember these mums and their children who won't be celebrating this year, and do your bit to help them.

"I'm doing my bit by supporting UNICEF's Mother's Day campaign and you can too.

"UNICEF is calling on everyone to buy a Nutritional Inspired Gift, which are life saving food supplies delivered directly to the mums and the children that need it most, like those in West Africa.

"My favourite is a special high protein paste  Plumpy Nut - which can take a child from the brink of death to healthy in a matter of weeks. You can help save a life for just £12, that's pretty amazing and that's exactly what I'll be buying my mum this Mother's Day.

This Mother's Day help a mum save their child's life and buy a nutritional UNICEF Inspired gift from www.unicef.org.uk/inspired. "

image.caption: A Mother's Day wish ... Louise Redknapp with her son

pages.subdeck: Volunteer ... Gail Porter spends her free time working in her local Save The Children store
pages.headline: Gail Porter: It feels good to give back
pages.teaser: TV presenter Gail Porter on why she has decided to volunteer in a charity shop
pages.articlebody:
IT isn't unusual to spot a celebrity such as Gail Porter in a trendy store full of designer gear.

But this is no ordinary shop, and the TV presenter isn't there to spend her cash  she is a member of staff.

Gail has been volunteering for the past month in one of retail tsar Mary Portas's special charity outlets.

The 40-year-old says: "The good thing about volunteering is that it's from the heart.

"You're not going in to do a nine-to-five job, you're doing it because it's something you genuinely want to do.

"I love every minute of it. I know the people who come in regularly and we'll go for a coffee together. I wake up feeling really excited about seeing everyone in the shop."

This urge to give her time for a good cause isn't part of a publicity stunt and it isn't a one-off appearance for the sake of our cameras.

And she wasn't the one to reveal her job to the world either.

It was picked up on by a local paper and her volunteering then became national news. Her reasons for helping out are genuine.

She says: "I'm about to turn 41, I've had a really good innings and I just want to do stuff for other people.

"It's karma. I've had lots of fun in my life and I've got lots of nice things and some people need help, so why not give a bit back? More people should be doing it."

The store in London's Primrose Hill is one of Mary Portas's five UK Living And Giving charity outlets, which raise cash for Save The Children.

They look nothing like a stereotypical charity shop. Instead they are beautifully decorated, community-focused boutiques filled with sumptuous goodies, some of which have been donated by fashion designers and businesses.

And former pin-up girl Gail has been doing regular shifts since she spotted a sign in the shop window asking for volunteers. Gail, mum to Honey, nine, says: "I do a lot of voiceovers for Nickelodeon, I do Sky News and The Wright Stuff on TV and I'm writing a book. But I've got no structure to my life.

"I said to the shop manager that I can't guarantee I'll be available at certain times but here's my number. If I can help in any way, I'd love to come in.

"Every week, the manager texts us to say how much the shop raised. It makes you feel really good.

"I would recommend it to anyone and I think more people in the limelight should be doing it.

"I know what the schedules are like in TV. You get made up, you do a couple of hours filming, then you've got time to work in your local charity shop for a while."

It's from this upmarket corner of London that Gail is slowly rebuilding her life after one of the worst years she has ever had.

Last April she was sectioned for almost a month after sending a despairing text to her then boyfriend, Jonny Davies, who feared for her welfare. She says: "I think that was the lowest point. My ex-husband Dan (Hipgrave  guitarist with the band Toploader) came over and said it was the worst he had seen me.

"I don't worry that it will happen again, I hope I've come through it. I still cry a lot. I'm up and down."

Gail  who famously had a snap of her naked body projected on to the the Houses of Parliament in 1999  has suffered from depression since she was a teenager. She has also battled anorexia.

She developed stress-related alopecia in 2005, which causes her hair to fall out. And in the last few years she has lost her mum, two grandparents and, most recently, her beloved dog Missy.

She says: "I haven't had the best few years, as everyone knows. I just want to feel better about myself and do things for other people. When I was low, I was very low and I would quite happily not get up each day. That's a real waste of time when you could be helping other people instead of feeling sorry for yourself.

"It's not the easiest thing in the world to get out and do it but it's just nice being around other people, knowing you're all doing something for others."

Gail, who says she may consider another stint in rehab to help further with her depression, explains that her daughter and ex-hubby  have been her towers of strength during these difficult times.

She says: "Honey has been brilliant and so has her dad. Dan has totally supported me through everything.

"It's quite odd, as when you're divorced you should want to kill each other, but he's been brilliant."

Now Gail has caught the volunteering bug she hopes to devote as much time as possible to charity work.

In between working on documentaries and writing a book about her experiences of being sectioned, Gail wants to help out at London Zoo, something Honey is feeling very jealous about. Gail is also training to compete in a triathlon to raise cash for The Children's Trust in Tadworth, Surrey.

She says: "I'm jogging for two hours a day. My problem is swimming. Honey is a much better swimmer than me."

For a woman who has been through so much, it's good to hear she still has her sense of humour. And she uses this in her occasional stand-up comedy gigs.

"I do it about my insane life," she says. "When you've got a problem and you talk about it in a funny way, people laugh nervously.

"It's so nerve-racking. I've been sick before going on stage but once you get the first laugh it's all right.

"I got loads of abuse when I first started losing my hair because I kept making jokes about it. I thought, 'Well, I've got it so I'm making fun of myself.'"

k.jackson@the-sun.co.uk

  • Mary's five Living And Giving Shops for Save The Children are appealing for donations and volunteers.

    To donate stock or to enquire about volunteering in any Save The Children shop, check out savethechildren.org.uk or call 020 7012 6400.

image.caption: Volunteer ... Gail Porter spends her free time working in her local Save The Children store

pages.subdeck: Gift ... Swati and Kanchan
pages.headline: I gave mum my kidney for Mother's Day
pages.teaser: A LOVING daughter gave her sick mum the ultimate Mother's Day gift  the kidney that saved her life
pages.articlebody:
A LOVING daughter gave her sick mum the ultimate Mother's Day gift  the kidney that saved her life.

Now mum-of-three Kanchan Bhagat and Swati are planning an extra special day tomorrow  to celebrate a year since their op.

Kanchan, 58, had suffered from kidney disease for 12 years when her condition suddenly worsened in 2010.

Doctors said she could die unless a donor was found quickly  and Swati, 30, stepped forward. The pair underwent a two-hour op and were both released from hospital on Mother's Day last year.

Swati, a healthcare professional, said: "Finding out it had been a success on Mothering Sunday was the best gift I could have given  even if I wasn't able to get her a card.

"When I first suggested donating a kidney, she was adamant I wasn't to risk my health for hers  but I wouldn't take no for an answer. Mum has always been there for me and I was able to show her how grateful I am."

Kanchan, who has returned to work at Sainsbury's, added: "Last Mother's Day was emotional. There was lots of joking because Swati's sister Heeta got me flowers but Swati hadn't bought anything. I said, 'It's OK  you have just given me a kidney'."

Kanchan, from Harrow, North West London, plans to spend this Sunday with her husband Suresh, 59, their son Piyush, 35, Swati and Heeta, 29.

a.parker@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Gift ... Swati and Kanchan

pages.subdeck: Baby ambition ... June dressed as boxer, doctor, matador, surfer and bishop
pages.headline: When I grow up I want to be a boxer
pages.teaser: FUNNY pictures show baby dressed in series of outfits showcasing what she may grow up to be
pages.articlebody:
A CREATIVE dad has given his three-month-old daughter insight into life as a grown-up through a series of funny costume photos.

Father-of-three Eric Maloberti dressed his little girl in outfits showcasing different career choices, for a project entitled Un Jour, Mon Enfant Tu Seras  which translates as One Day, My Child You Will Be.

The amusing snaps show June wearing everything from a mini bishop outfit to a boxer's kit and gloves  with a fake black eye to match.

The photographer  known as Malo  and his wife designed the costumes to show what life can hold when babies grow up.

And baby June was his inspiration, giving him the idea of photographically capturing the fears every parent has for what their child will become.

Malo, 39, said: "The idea behind the project is that we do not know what our children will become.

"As parents we do hope for our children to become symbols and icons, like an athlete, a Miss Something pageant queen or a rock star.

"I found the idea amusing and so began my project."

The couple, who live in Paris, said they produced the pictures "very quickly" to ensure June would not get tired.

Malo explained his reasons behind the project  to tell parents they should want their children to do whatever makes them happy.

He said: "I want people to look at these pictures and be touched and think of their children.

"The innocence of babies is what resonates with the public and on a serious note I would want other mums and dads to look at their kids and think what would make them happiest when they grow up."

He added: "If your child wants to be a priest then tell them they can be and if your child wants to be a bishop tell them that is good too."

image.caption: Baby ambition ... June dressed as boxer, doctor, matador, surfer and bishop

pages.subdeck: Gleeful ... One Direction
pages.headline: One Direction's Glee
pages.teaser: BAND'S hit tune What Makes You Beautiful is to be sung on the smash hit American series
pages.articlebody:
ONE Direction's hit tune What Makes You Beautiful is to feature on smash US TV series Glee.

Matthew Morrison, who plays teacher Will Schuester, is going to croon the song as the boyband takes another step towards world domination.

The lads are expected to be over the moon about the honour  which comes as they celebrate their album Up All Night debuting at No1 in the US charts last week.

Actor Matt says he will be watching the group performing the single online so that he knows it inside out before doing his own version.

But he admitted he has only recently got to know about the former X Factor band  which has legions of screaming teen fans.

He said: "I've just heard of them, they're really taking over the States.

"We are covering one of their songs on Glee  What Makes You Beautiful.

"I need to YouTube it to practise."

And he predicted that the song's high-profile appearance on the all-singing all-dancing soap, seen here on Channel 4, is likely to make the band even BIGGER.

Matthew  who was a Broadway star before getting the telly gig  joked: "They've made it now though, they're on Glee!

"This will probably help their record sales too."

The song was the group's debut single and hit No1 in the UK last year  but only No19 in the US.

image.caption: Gleeful ... One Direction

article.caption: Cheryl jokes One Direction's success is down to her

pages.subdeck: Xtra host ... Olly Murs will appear on next series of Xtra Factor
pages.headline: Olly Murs Factors in tour
pages.teaser: SINGER will host just live shows of Xtra Factor after clash with One Direction tour
pages.articlebody:
OLLY Murs has confirmed that he WILL host the next series of The Xtra Factor.

There were fears he would quit the ITV2 spin-off show because he would be busy supporting One Direction on their US tour.

The gigs  which kick off at the end of May  clash with The X Factor auditions so the singer will only join the programme for the live shows in the autumn.

A show source said:

"X Factor bosses loved Olly on last year's show and really wanted him to do it.

"Once the One Direction tour was confirmed we decided to offer him just the live shows instead."

His Xtra Factor sidekick Caroline Flack  who used to date One Direction's Harry Styles  will front the audition-based Xtra Factors by herself. The deal is being finalised by Olly's management and X Factor chiefs.

pages.subdeck: BBack ... Celebrity Big Brother is returning for second time this year
pages.headline: CBB returns for second time
pages.teaser: CELEBRITY Big Brother is returning to telly for a second time this year in the summer
pages.articlebody:
CELEBRITY Big Brother is returning to telly for a second time this year.

The show  won by Loose Women star Denise Welch earlier this year  is expected to air again this summer along with the standard version, which features members of the public.

Amy Childs, Jedward and Kerry Katona have been among the contestants on the show since it moved to Channel 5 last year.

Former Corrie actress Denise was crowned ahead of X Factor reject Frankie Cocozza.

The show was launched in the UK in 2000 after it had been a big hit in the Netherlands.

It made stars of contestants including Ryanair flight attendant Brian Dowling, who went on to present SMTV Live and become one of the first openly gay children's TV presenters, and Jade Goody.

pages.subdeck: Grin and Bear it ... Dermot O'Leary
pages.headline: Dermot worms way onto Grylls' tour
pages.teaser: X FACTOR host shocks fans after he eats WORMS during the adventurer's live tour
pages.articlebody:
BEAR Grylls fans were shocked when Dermot O'Leary ate WORMS on stage at the TV adventurer's live tour.

The show re-lives some of the great escapes and sticky situations of Bear's life as a soldier, mountaineer and Man vs Wild star.

Dermot was watching the show on Monday night with fiancée Dee Koppang  when they were both dragged on stage to chomp the worms.

An onlooker said: "The worms were still alive and wriggling around."

Other famous fans were also in the audience. Holly Valance tweeted: "AWESOME show, man."

image.caption: Grin and Bear it ... Dermot O'Leary

pages.subdeck: Bad lad ... EastEnders' Michael Moon as played by Steve John Shepherd
pages.headline: Enders Michael Moon is a loon
pages.teaser: ACTOR Steve John Shepherd says character is plotting to snatch fiancee's money
pages.articlebody:
EASTENDERS baddie Michael Moon is a "psychopath" according to Steve John Shepherd, who plays him.

And he reckons Michael's fiancée, Janine Butcher, could be in danger as he plots to snatch her millions.

Steve revealed Michael hatches the plan after Janine insists he signs a pre-nuptial agreement.

Steve said: "Her insistence that he sign suggests she doesn't trust him.

"But Michael's plotting something. I see him as a functioning psychopath.

"He can be very cold."

pages.subdeck: Hunt ... Coronation Street are looking for a hunk to play Carla Connor's (pictured) brother
pages.headline: Hunk wanted for Corrie
pages.teaser: SOAP bosses are searching for brooding new heartbreaker  to play Carla Connor's mysterious brother
pages.articlebody:
CORONATION Street bosses are searching for a brooding new heartbreaker to play Carla Connor's mysterious brother.

They want a moody bad boy to set the cobbles' women aflutter.

Bosses are currently auditioning hopefuls and the new character will arrive in the ITV1 series in the summer.

An insider said: "We are seeing lots of different actors over the next week or so.

"We have got some exciting storylines lined up for Carla's brother. He is a character the fans have been keen to meet for some time." The brother will arrive on the Street to help Carla run the knicker factory Underworld.

Carla, played by Alison King, has often mentioned her brother over the past couple of years but has given few details.

She has not even revealed his name, although she has said he is in his thirties.

Bosses say he will ruffle feathers by wasting no time launching himself at Weatherfield's most glamorous ladies.

pages.subdeck: Mum ... Sarah Cawood
pages.headline: Baby boy for telly's Sarah Cawood
pages.teaser: TOP Of The Pops presenter has become a mum for the first time  after giving birth to 8lb 5oz little son Hunter
pages.articlebody:
TV presenter Sarah Cawood became a mum for the first time yesterday  giving birth to 8lb 5oz boy Hunter.

Sarah, who is engaged to TV producer Andy Merry, joked: "When can I have a gin? It's been nine months.

"Andy and I are thrilled and slightly terrified at the thought of taking a new member of our family home with us. Hunter is a beautiful, healthy baby boy with long legs, just like his dad."

Sarah, who suffered a miscarriage last year, is expected to return to her north London home from hospital later this week.

The presenter  who made her name in the Nineties on programmes including The Girlie Show before going on to host Live & Kicking, Top Of The Pops and the Eurovision Song Contest  is due to wed Andy in a Christmas ceremony this year.

She said: "Our plan has come together  to have a baby, then get married.

"2012 is proving to be the most exciting year of our lives."

image.caption: Mum ... Sarah Cawood

pages.subdeck: Cole position ... Cheryl is a beauty queen
pages.headline: Cheryl shares beauty secrets
pages.teaser: FORMER telly judge reveals some of the amaizng tips that give her the X Factor
pages.articlebody:
CHERYL Cole has revealed some of the beauty secrets that give her the X Factor.

The former telly judge said that she always takes her make-up off at night and moisturises.

But she has a secret weapon  eyeliner.

The sultry star feels naked without the product  saying it's her signature look.

She told Stylist magazine: "I use a liquid liner across the top of my lashes. Starting in the corner of the eye and following it across, then I always use a black kohl for the inside of the eye and just smudge it in.

"It takes a while to actually get there, but I think it's quite easy to do. And remember, everyone's eyes are different, so you just have to go with it."

Cheryl, who gained fame as one fifth of Girls Aloud, is often seen looking effortlessly glamorous at showbiz bashes.

But the star has said that she sometimes looks back at some of her old beauty looks from her days in the band and can't believe that she pulled them off.

"Sometimes I think a certain look was actually ahead of its time, like the black and white eyes in the Sexy! No No No video. On the day, it was wacky. But now you look at Lady Gaga or different big make-up looks and it seems really normal. I like to make a bit of a statement."

And treading the red carpet is still "terrifying" to the seasoned star.

"We once had this nightmare where my dress ripped here, somebody was sewing here, my nail had just chipped so somebody was painting them. Then I walked out, tripped in the middle of the corridor, grabbed the security guy and tore all my nail polish off. I had burgundy nail polish all down my white dress.

"So I said 'Wait until I figure out how I am going to manoeuvre this handbag so that my nails are covered.'

"So, that's how I walked down the carpet. It was absolute pandemonium. Anyone who says that they love red carpets is lying. Getting dressed up is the best part. And champagne after the event  that's even better."

For the full interview visit the Stylist website.

image.caption: Cole position ... Cheryl is a beauty queen

pages.subdeck: Birds Of A Feather back together ... Linda Robson, Lesley Joseph and Pauline Quirke on stage
pages.headline: Birds of a Feather are back together
pages.teaser: SITCOM stars Pauline Quirke and Linda Robson reunite for new stage show - and their teenage sons join the cast too
pages.articlebody:
IT'S been over 13 years since they were last on screen, but the Birds of a Feather are finally back together.

Original sitcom stars Pauline Quirke, Linda Robson and Lesley Joseph have been reunited for a stage show based on the TV series which ran from 1989 to 1998.

And after losing a whopping amount of weight between them, the stars are now half the size they were back in the 1990s!

As sisters and original Essex girls Sharon and Tracy, Pauline and Linda lived next door to man-eater Dorien (played by Lesley). While their husbands were in prison for armed robbery, Sharon and Tracy lived it up in a Chigwell mansion, and neighbour Dorien had affairs with toyboys.

Now, as the trio of old friends reunite for the stage show  written by original show creators Laurence Marks and Maurice Gran  it's a real family affair, as Pauline and Linda's sons  who are both actors  have joined the cast.

Pauline's son Charlie Quirke and Linda's son Louis Dunford are sharing the role of Sharon's 16-year-old son, Travis.

The Birds of a Feather stage show is currently on at the New Victoria Theatre in Woking, then from April to July will tour around the UK.

article.caption: 'I'm so glad I won't be kissing any more blokes'

image.caption: Birds Of A Feather back together ... Linda Robson, Lesley Joseph and Pauline Quirke on stage

pages.subdeck: Standing by her sister ... Khloe Kardashian
pages.headline: Khloe drops PETA after Kim Kardashian flour bombing stunt
pages.teaser: STAR cut ties with animal charity after her sister was targeted
pages.articlebody:
KHLOE Kardashian has cut ties with animal charity PETA after learning that her sister's flour-bombing stunt was allegedly performed by someone linked to the organisation.

Four years after Khloe, 27, posed naked for the infamous "I'd rather go naked than wear fur" campaign, the TV star posted a statement on her website severing her alliance with them.

PETA has denied any connection to the stunt  widely reported as carried out by animal-activist Christina Cho who is associated with the company and won an award from them in 2010.

Refusing to confirm the identity of the person, they said they would look at how to maximise exposure caused by the event.

But Khloe wrote online: "Not only has PETA lied to the public, but they have proved that they support this kind of behaviour."

And added: "I've been a vocal supporter of PETA for a long time but I have also been very vocal about anti-bullying, so this was a huge disappointment for me.

"I personally don't wear fur but that doesn't mean I am going to force my views on anyone else, ESPECIALLY by violating them. ... Bullying and harassment is NEVER a solution, and I won't be a part of any organization that thinks otherwise."

Last week Kim was hit by a flour bomb as she launches her new fragrance.

The reality show star was chatting on the red carpet when a packet of the white powder was dumped on her head.

It spoilt the carefully selected outfit of leather trousers, blue shirt and black blazer.

The 31-year-old had just arrived at the London Hotel in West Hollywood to promote her new scent True Reflections when she was attacked.

As she chatted, a female onlooker produced a bag of flour and, despite heavy security, threw it at the star.

article.caption: Kim Kardashian wants Beckingham Palace
Kim's fighting back at 'careless' Jon Hamm

image.caption: Standing by her sister ... Khloe Kardashian

pages.subdeck: Expecting again ... Nicola McLean reveals she's pregnant with baby number three
pages.headline: Nicola McLean announces she's expecting again
pages.teaser: CELEB Big Bro star Nicola McLean is "shocked but pleased" to be pregnant with child number three
pages.articlebody:
NICOLA McLean has said she is "shocked but pleased" to discover she is pregnant again.

The Celebrity Big Brother contestant has announced that she is six weeks pregnant with her third child with footballer husband Tom Williams.

And Nicola, 30, admitted the news was unexpected, as she thought her battles with bulimia had left her unable to have any more children.

"I'm so shocked but very pleased," said the glamour model.

"To be honest, because of how ill I've been with my eating disorder, my periods had stopped and I thought I'd blown any chance of having more kids so I was pretty devastated, because I want a house full.

"But suddenly my periods started coming back, which meant I was getting better."

The baby will be the third child for Nicola and Tom, who already have sons Rocky (four) and Striker (two).

And the mum-to-be says she would love to have a little girl to even things up.

"I'd love a girl but I'd also be happy with a boy because I love going to football, but I would love all the ballet and tutus too!" she added, in an interview with OK! magazine.

"I love children, I love being a mum and having a big family."

article.caption: Nic kicks off her heels on wild night out
Nicola McLean: My bulimia is back because of Denise Welch

image.caption: Expecting again ... Nicola McLean reveals she's pregnant with baby number three

pages.subdeck: Yellow fever ... Freema Agyeman walks down Wall Street in her 1980s get-up
pages.headline: Freema goes back in time for Manhattan role
pages.teaser: FORMER Doctor Who star Freema Agyeman spotted filming Sex And The City prequel in NYC
pages.articlebody:
IT looks like Freema Agyeman has been borrowing the TARDIS again  to head back to the 1980s.

The former Doctor Who star was spotted on the streets of Manhattan, filming the new Sex And The City prequel, The Carrie Diaries.

Freema, who played David Tennant's sidekick Martha Jones, is playing magazine journalist Larissa in the show, which follows Carrie Bradshaw's arrival in New York.

And her fashion was certainly a bright blast from the past, as she wore a bright yellow coat, blue parachute pant jumpsuit, bright pink plastic earrings and leopard print heels.

Freema, 33, was snapped walking down Wall Street with teen star AnnaSophia Rob, who plays the young Carrie  the role made famous by Sarah Jessica Parker. And it's obvious that Carrie's love of style started early, as AnnaSophia (18) is shown with a personalised handbag, daubed with Carrie in bright pink and covered in paint splashes, and has her hair in SJP's signature messy blonde curls.
