pages.subdeck: Back-less beauty ... January Jones looks classy in couture
pages.headline: January looks classy in couture for night at the opera
pages.teaser: MAD Men star January Jones celebrates the show's return to the screen with a classical night out
pages.articlebody:
IT was a night at the opera for January Jones, as she celebrated the triumphant return of Mad Men to American screens.

The stunning actress plays Betty in the smash-hit American drama series, which came back for the fifth series in America on Sunday night and which starts back in the UK tonight.

Mum-of-one January showed off her slender frame in a long black couture dress as she attended the gala premiere of Jules Massenet's 'Manon' at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York.

And she seemed to take inspiration from Angelina Jolie's infamous Oscars pose, by giving photographers a flash of her thigh as she posed on the red carpet.

Mad Men returns tonight (Tuesday) at 9pm, on Sky Atlantic.

pages.subdeck: Jenkins the jiver ... Katherine with her partner Mark Ballas
pages.headline: Jenkins the jiver wows the judges
pages.teaser: SEXY opera star Katherine tops the leaderboard on Dancing With The Stars
pages.articlebody:
WE'VE always known she's got a great set of lungs on her, but now sexy singer Katherine Jenkins is proving she's got quite a pair of legs, too.

The Welsh opera star is currently competing in Dancing With The Stars  America's answer to Strictly Come Dancing  and has topped the leaderboard for two weeks running.

Katherine, 31, wowed the judges and the audience with a sizzling jive  and with her long, tanned legs which were shown off by her short fringed black and pink dress.

The classical star and her professional partner Mark Ballas impressed judges including Strictly's Bruno Tonioli and Len Goodman, earning a whopping 26 out of 30 points.

Although head judge Len did say he thought the middle section of the dance 'wasn't his cup of tea', as it was 'wild and wacky'.

But Italian Bruno loved it, and praised Katherine by saying: "The blonde bombshell is unleashed. I know sexy when I see it and you've got it."

Katherine Jenkins looks sleek for LA dinner

pages.subdeck: WE'RE COMING FOR BLUE ... Bale teases home to set up Chelsea semi-final
pages.headline: It's Wemberglee for Bale
pages.teaser: GARETH BALE helped send Spurs to Wembley for a London derby with Chelsea
pages.articlebody:
GARETH BALE helped send Spurs to Wembley for a capital crunch with Chelsea.

Fans and players paid tribute to Fabrice Muamba on an emotional night at White Hart Lane.

Then goals from Ryan Nelsen, Bale and Louis Saha sealed an FA Cup semi against the Blues on April 15.

Bale said: "It's fantastic to go to Wembley for the fans.

"We know we have difficult opposition with Chelsea in the semi-final but we will give it a right go."

Liverpool and Everton meet in a Mersey derby in the other semi on April 14. And Spurs boss Harry Redknapp said: "They are two fantastic semis, it should be a great weekend at Wembley."

Trotters keeper Adam Bogdan made a string of top stops before Nelsen beat him on 74 minutes.

Bale made it two and although Kevin Davies pulled one back, Saha scored with the last kick of the game.

Redknapp added: "I've never seen the keeper make so many saves.

"It was save after save, we hit the woodwork, we just couldn't get a break.

"We pummelled them, he continued to make saves but eventually the goals came."

Bolton chief Owen Coyle wrote a message in last night's match programme thanking everyone at Spurs for their support following Muamba's collapse with a cardiac arrest, which led to the original game being abandoned.

He said: "We have been truly humbled by the care and concern shown by you all for Fabrice."

Redknapp added: "Just over a week ago, we all left White Hart Lane fearing the worst.

"We are not quite there yet but it has been a miracle for the boy the way he has recovered so far."

image.caption: WE'RE COMING FOR BLUE ... Bale teases home to set up Chelsea semi-final
Gareth Bale joy at Spurs derby date

article.caption: Tottenham 3 Bolton 1

pages.subdeck: UP BEFORE THE BEAK ... Benfica eagle steals the show
pages.headline: Blues' eagle has landed
pages.teaser: STEVEN HOWARD sees Blues catch their prey in front of the Benfica eagle
pages.articlebody:
THE Benfica eagle soared and swooped with matchless power and grace round the Stadium of Light.

What a sight to behold, what a way to herald kick-off.

It was spectacular, mesmerising and menacing.

And yet in the end it was a Chelsea predator who swooped  and stooped  to conquer as Salomon Kalou slid in to covert a Fernando Torres cross 15 minutes from time.

It might not have been quite as magnificent as what we had witnessed earlier but no Blues fan will be complaining.

Instead, they will be applauding an old-fashioned England performance in Europe, one with a certain Jose Mourinho touch to it.

Pragmatic. A means to an end. A Chelsea team going out to do a job.

A question, first, of containment. And then the application of the killer touch.

Yes, they had a couple of close calls but for their overall display and the manner in which they went about the task at hand, they more than deserved that.

At the centre of it all was a defence that has had more than its share of criticism this season  and a defence, at that, minus the redoubtable Branislav Ivanovic.

David Luiz, one of the most criticised of all, was peerless on his return to the Stadium of Light while, alongside him, skipper John Terry was back to his most solid and reliable best.

Ashley Cole never wavered and you couldn't even fault the once high-risk Paulo Ferreira, making only his third start of the season.

And so it all comes thick and fast for Chelsea.

A trip to Villa Park, one of their least favourite grounds, on Saturday.

And the thought at the back of everyone's minds that, with the spectre of Barcelona looming, the only certain way of qualifying for next season's Champions League is to somehow close the five-point gap separating them from Tottenham and fourth place.

But, for the moment, Chelsea fans are toasting a team with one foot in this season's semi-final.

Throw in another last-four date  with Spurs in the FA Cup  and it's all looking a lot more encouraging than it once did.

Chelsea had gone into the game as the last standard-bearers of English football.

It has been as poor a season in Europe as it could have been for those teams who had dominated the Champions League for almost a decade.

But Chelsea are still there, flying the flag and defending the battered reputation of our top clubs after one of their grittiest displays this term.

It was all far removed from the 4-0 thrashing Arsenal suffered at the San Siro.

All far removed from the 3-1 beating Chelsea themselves were handed in Naples.

And certainly a world away from the 2-0 defeat that could have been four or five that Manchester United collapsed to in Bilbao.

That Blues interim boss Roberto Di Matteo left Didier Drogba, Frank Lampard, Michael Essien and Daniel Sturridge on the bench was the clearest indication that he wanted to make sure there was still a tie for Chelsea to contest back at Stamford Bridge.

He didn't want all the trauma of having to overturn the sort of two-goal lead Napoli had taken to West London last time out.

So he fielded a team with players to cover, drop back in defence and stymie a Benfica team that had scored in every home game this season  and that meant younger legs in front of the back four.

Yes, Luiz had to clear off the line early in the second half.

At the same time, Juan Mata almost put Chelsea ahead on the hour with a shot that came back off a post.

And then, as the Blues back four started to creak, Jardel should have buried a header that keeper Petr Cech somehow scrambled away. Kalou, though, made no mistake with the game's defining moment.

No, Benfica were not the toughest draw. And they certainly didn't live up to any of the advance publicity.

Yes, it was nice to watch, all pretty enough in its own way. But, unlike their eagle, the hosts didn't have the fear factor.

Lampard says Chelsea are not as good as they used to be  and last night they didn't necessarily have to be.

But they did more than enough. And so the journey continues.

image.caption: UP BEFORE THE BEAK ... Benfica eagle steals the show
JOY ... Torres, Mata 'n Kalou
Steven Howard's big-match verdict

article.caption: How Chelsea rated
Q&A on Blues' glory night

pages.subdeck: KING SALOMON ... Kalou celebrates his goal with Fernando Torres
pages.headline: Kalou: No worries over new deal
pages.teaser: SALOMON KALOU insists he is not concerned about his Chelsea contract running out in the summer
pages.articlebody:
SALOMON KALOU insists he is not concerned about his Chelsea contract running out in the summer.

The Ivorian forward was the hero as the Blues beat Benfica 1-0 in the Champions League quarter-final first leg last night.

It was his first start in Europe since December 2010 and only the eighth time he has been named in the starting XI this season.

Kalou said: "I know my contract ends at the end of the season.

"For me the most important thing is not to fight for a new deal.

"I'm just to enjoying myself with the team and play the best I can and help the team win the games we have left to play.

"As long as I do that, I am fine and I am happy with myself."

Kalou has featured more since Roberto Di Matteo replaces Andre Villas-Boas as Chelsea manager.

He added: "I think the idea is to give an opportunity for everyone to show that they want to play for the club and give 100 per cent.

"That is how you get everybody behind you and that is how you get the team to work together."

Chelsea are on the brink of the Champions League semi-finals just weeks after their European campaign seemed in tatters.

Kalou was proud to net last night's all-important goal and believes anything is possible in this season's competition.

He said: "It means a lot to me to score. I am happy to be in the team, playing games and to score.

"I still think I can improve and if I can help teams to win games, I'd be delighted to do that.

"Anything is possible. We have the team for it, we have the players for it.

"I believe there is no reason why we could not win the Champions League."

image.caption: KING SALOMON ... Kalou celebrates his goal with Fernando Torres

article.caption: Estadio Da Bluz
Chelsea Dream Team ratings
How Chelsea rated
Blues' eagle has landed
FA snub RDM bid

pages.subdeck: PRICELESS ... Salomon Kalou slots home from a Fernando Torres cross
pages.headline: Benfica 0 Chelsea 1
pages.teaser: SALOMON KALOU slotted a priceless away goal for Blues at the Stadium of Light
pages.articlebody:
CHELSEA have had a few goes at it but, at last, they held on to a lead.

And now they are hot favourites for a place in the Champions League semi-finals for a sixth time in nine years.

On four occasions on their travels in Europe this season, the Blues had been ahead without winning once.

But forgotten man Salomon Kalou's vital 75th-minute goal from Fernando Torres' perfect pass silenced Benfica's crowd in the magnificent Estadio da Luz.

Kalou showed the same predatory skills as Eusebio against the Portugal legend's old club.

And it earned Chelsea their first away success on the continent in 13 months.

Kalou is a man reborn under Roberto Di Matteo. The Ivorian barely figured for Chelsea when Andre Villas-Boas was in charge.

But since Di Matteo took command earlier this month he has come right back into the reckoning.

The 26-year-old is out of contract in the summer and is tipped for a possible move to Arsenal.

But his issue at Stamford Bridge has never been about money, it is about getting regular games.

This strike will certainly have helped his argument, although it is unlikely Di Matteo will be in charge to have a say about his future.

For now, though, the pair are enjoying themselves and Di Matteo hoisted Kalou into the air at the final whistle in celebration.

The Champions League is treating the interim boss very well. He has a 100 per cent record from two games.

The Italian masterminded the extraordinary turnaround against Napoli in the previous round and now this in the first leg of the quarter-final.

Yet before kick-off, we wondered if he had signed his own death warrant the way Villas-Boas did when he axed the old guard for the last-16 first-leg game in Naples and lost 3-1.

Frank Lampard, Didier Drogba and Michael Essien were all dumped on the bench last night.

Yet there was a shock recall for another oldie, 33-year-old Paulo Ferreira, who was picked at right-back having not featured at all since the New Year's eve defeat against Aston Villa. Ferreira coped well  in what was only his third start of the season  against the much-hyped Argie Nicolas Gaitan.

He was part of a very well oiled Chelsea defensive machine of which David Luiz was the star.

Luiz was back at the club where he made his name and marked his performance with a crucial chest block on the line from Paraguayan striker Oscar Cardozo's volley just after half-time.

He also showed incredible coolness in the first half to control a ball on his knee right in front of keeper Petr Cech before volleying it away.

Di Matteo has made the point that Chelsea are much tighter defensively these days and the manager must take credit for that. They were immense in keeping out Spurs last Saturday and once more were right on it in Lisbon.

It was not until late in the first half that Chelsea offered any real threat going forward when Torres, preferred to Drogba, worked himself some space in the penalty area only to curl his shot a yard over the bar.

Then Torres picked out Kalou, who laid a ball back for Raul Meireles and he caught it flush from 30 yards, forcing a smart save from Artur going full length to his left.

With the scores level at half-time, the visitors could be well satisfied with their efforts. Being greedy, an away goal was the ideal for Di Matteo's men to make it a perfect night's work.

But first they survived when Luiz made his block and the referee ignored the home fans' screams for a penalty as they claimed their former hero handled.

Then Torres crossed from the left and Kalou was in space to meet the header but he put it over when he should have done better.

There was another escape for Chelsea as Maxi Pereira's volleyed cross hit skipper John Terry's arm at close range.

The crowd were again baying for a penalty and their tempers would have gone up another notch had Juan Mata (right) scored when he latched on to Cech's long kick. The Spaniard went round the keeper but hit the outside of the post with the angle narrowing.

Alex Witsel's shot landed on the roof of the net after deflecting off Terry and Cech beat out a header from Jardel.

Lampard came on to replace Meireles in a stadium where he scored three goals for England at Euro 2004 and another in the penalty shootout when they lost to Portugal in the quarter-finals.

He will have fancied his chances of adding to his tally on this ground but it was left to the unsung Kalou to do the damage.

Ramires, like Luiz a former Benfica star, fed Torres down the right and the striker bustled his way into the area.

Torres took a quick look up before playing a delightful ball across the six-yard box where Kalou converted.

It has been such a strange season for Chelsea yet they are still fighting in two cup competitions, with their FA Cup semi-final now confirmed as being against Tottenham.

Who knows how this will all end.

DREAM TEAM

STAR MAN  DAVID LUIZ (CHELSEA)

CHELSEA: Cech 7, Ferreira 7, Luiz 8, Terry 7, Cole 7, Ramires 6, Meireles 7, Mata 6, Mike 7, Kalou 7, Torres 7. Subs: Lampard (Meireles 68) 6, Bosingwa (Ferreira 80) 5, Sturridge (Kalou 82) 5. Not used: Turnbull, Essien, Drogba, Cahill. Booked: Meireles.

pages.subdeck: BRAINS TRUST ... Ferdy has put his faith in United savvy
pages.headline: Rio: We'll stay cool
pages.teaser: DEFENDER Ferdinand insists Man United's know-how will make the difference
pages.articlebody:
RIO FERDINAND insists Manchester United have the know-how to claim title No 20.

The edgy champions almost threw away two points on Monday before finally beating Fulham 1-0 to move three points clear of rivals City at the top.

But England defender Ferdinand, 33, said: "It happens every year and at this stage of the season we know what it takes and we've got comfort in the knowledge we can create chances and remain calm.

"You've got to hold your nerve but as important as that, if not more so, is trusting each other.

"United have the experience, City have the hunger."

image.caption: BRAINS TRUST ... Ferdy has put his faith in United savvy

pages.subdeck: DZEKING OUT ... Edin could be off
pages.headline: Dzeko may be Edin for exit
pages.teaser: THE Bosnian is unhappy on the bench, while the Germans may lose their top striker
pages.articlebody:
BORUSSIA DORTMUND are lining up a summer swoop for Manchester City forward Edin Dzeko.

The Bosnian is unhappy with his limited starts, while the Bundesliga high-fliers face losing Polish top scorer Robert Lewandowski.

City are interested in the 23-year-old forward so may suggest a swap deal.

But Dzeko's agent Irfan Redzepagic insists: "He is not thinking about leaving."

pages.subdeck: GATECRASHER ... Mario Balotelli interrupts Inter Milan's press conference
pages.headline: Madcap Balo gatecrashes Inter
pages.teaser: MANCHESTER CITY striker wanders into press conference in Milan
pages.articlebody:
MADCAP Manchester City striker Mario Balotelli just can't stay out of the spotlight.

The 21-year-old gatecrashed a press conference his old side Inter Milan were giving to announce the arrival of new boss Andrea Stramaccioni.

Grinning hitman Balo wandered into proceedings in the Italian city as journalists quizzed Stramaccioni on his plans to save stuttering Inter's season.

Balotelli shook hands with the new man in charge as well as other members of Inter's top brass.

The San Siro side lie eighth in Serie A and sacked Claudio Ranieri as manager last night after winning just ONE of their last 10 league games.

Inter are a mammoth 22 points off leaders and bitter rivals AC Milan, facing a struggle to qualify for next season's Champions League.

Watch footage of Balotelli's interruption below.

pages.subdeck: CHELSEA SANDWICH ... David Luiz (left) and Paulo Ferreira crowd out Oscar Cardozo
pages.headline: Ferreira: It's great to be back
pages.teaser: PAULO FERREIRA delighted to return against Benfica and says Chelsea can win Champions League
pages.articlebody:
PAULO FERREIRA was delighted to return to the Chelsea side against Benfica and believes the Blues can still win the Champions League.

The Portuguese full-back, 33, had been frozen out at Stamford Bridge, making just five appearances all season before last night's quarter-final first leg.

But interim boss Roberto Di Matteo surprisingly included Ferreira in his starting line-up at the Stadium of Light yesterday as Chelsea ran out 1-0 winners.

Ferreira said: "I am happy because I was not playing for a long time.

"Every day I do my work and try to be in a good condition for the manager if he wants to use me.

"I know that I can do even better than I did today but in physical terms I knew I couldn't make crazy runs so I had to play with more intelligence.

"I did the best I could and I was happy because I helped the team get a good result.

"But we know it's not finished. Benfica can score goals away and we need to be careful.

"Playing at home with our supporters in our stadium we will do everything we can to pass this stage.

"I still believe we can win the Champions League. We have wonderful players."

pages.subdeck: WELL JEL ... Nikica Jelavic celebrates his 24th minute opener
pages.headline: Sunderland 0 Everton 2
pages.teaser: EVERTON set up semi with Liverpool thanks to Nikica Jelavic and David Vaughan's o.g
pages.articlebody:
DAVID MOYES needed help from the cops to set up a Wembley crunch with the Kop.

Everton arrived at the Stadium of Light more than half an hour late because of traffic mayhem and problems with their convoy.

But they were certainly up to speed on the pitch in the way they sealed a Wembley date with their old rivals from across Stanley Park.

Nikica Jelavic put them in control on 24 minutes before a comical David Vaughan own goal after the break sealed the deal.

It was no more than the Merseysiders deserved. Sunderland were blown away, putting in the kind of display which got Steve Bruce the sack.

Marouane Fellaini and Tim Cahill were outstanding and Moyes said: "If we hadn't won tonight there would have been something wrong.

"We got here a little bit late and I hear it's quite regular up here. That bolstered us, gave us a wee edge.

"Quite a few things didn't go right and we should have maybe won by a few more goals. But it was a great win.

"Liverpool will be favourites. They've beaten us twice this season so they'll go in as favourites. We'll go down there and play  sometimes it suits us being an underdog."

In truth, it was more than comfortable for Everton who could have won by at least five.

Disappointed Black Cats boss Martin O'Neill admitted: "The expectations were high having done so well to get here. But you have to perform, pass and control under pressure and we didn't do it well enough.

"If you cannot do the simple things then you have no chance."

These two looked evenly matched in the first game 10 days ago.But at the end of 90 pulsating minutes, they were miles apart.

Sunderland's best player was keeper Simon Mignolet  enough said.

The Belgian kept out the rampaging Cahill and Jelavic but the Croatian would not be denied on 24 minutes. Fellaini fed Magaye Gueye down the left and Jelavic took advantage of some horrific marking from the hapless Sotirios Kyrgiakos to ram home the low cross.

Cue complete and utter bedlam in among the 6,000 in the away end.

For the home side, Bendtner almost got hold of a James McClean cross on the half-hour before Sebastian Larsson curled a free-kick just wide.

But within 90 seconds of the restart Leon Osman nearly sealed it with a brilliant volley which whistled just wide.

O'Neill hauled off Kyrgiakos for Vaughan. But just four minutes after coming on the Welshman slotted into his own net after Mignolet had half-stopped a Jelavic shot that did not seem to be going in.

Vaughan somehow managed to take one touch with his left foot before sliding home with his right.

Stephane Sessegnon smacked the bar two minutes later, but Tim Howard still had not made a save.

Jelavic continued to cause panic in the shaky Sunderland backline and only the Croatian will know how he failed to make it three on 61 minutes.

Tempers frayed late on  with ref Lee Probert booking three players  when handbags were thrown after Phil Neville appeared to catch McClean with an elbow.

Unfortunately for O'Neill, it was the only time his side showed any real fight and urgency. Liverpool ought to beware their neighbours.

DREAM TEAM

SUNDERLAND 0 EVERTON 2

STAR MAN  MAROUANE FELLAINI (EVERTON)

SUNDERLAND: Mignolet 7, Bardsley 6, Kyrgiakos (Vaughan 5) 5, Turner 5, Bridge (Campbell 6) 5, Larsson 6, Cattermole 5, Gardner 5, McClean 5, Sessegnon 5, Bendtner 5. Not used: Gordon, Kilgallon, Ji, Meyler, Elmohamady. Booked: Bardsley, Larsson, Cattermole.

pages.subdeck: BOG ROLE ... Adam Bogdan dazzles against Spurs
pages.headline: Tottenham 3 Bolton 1
pages.teaser: MESSAGES were relayed to Fabrice Muamba  and they all would have said: "What a save from Adam Bogdan!"
pages.articlebody:
FABRICE MUAMBA must have been sitting in hospital, shaking his head and thinking his phone was on the blink.

He was supposed to be receiving regular updates from White Hart Lane on this replayed FA Cup quarter-final.

But, for almost 74 minutes, every message would have read the same: "Unbelievable save from Adam Bogdan!"

If Muamba was the story of the first curtailed encounter, the 24-year-old Hungarian keeper was the star this time.

He was sensational, producing a remarkable run of saves of the highest quality to walk away with the Man of the Match award.

But not the night's big prize, an April 15 trip to face Chelsea at Wembley.

Ryan Nelsen's header finally broke his resistance with a quarter of an hour left.

And, like a London bus there was another goal along moments later as Gareth Bale made it 2-0 just three minutes afterwards.

Bolton sub Kevin Davies pulled one back with a minute to go but Tottenham sub Louis Saha went one better with a superb strike in the final second.

There was not even enough time to kick-off again.

So it was a comfortable win in the end, but for long spells it looked an unlikely one because of the one-man defiance from that man Bogdan.

Bale tested the keeper after just five minutes, and Bogdan followed that up with a stunning double effort to deny first Jake Livermore and then Luka Modric.

Midway through the half Bogdan produced another astonishing double stop, first getting down low to frustrate Adebayor at the near post then Bale at the far.

Bolton just were not in it.

Their first contribution, in the 35th minute, was an awful Darren Pratley tackle on Bale which brought a double whammy punishment for the visiting midfielder.

Pratley was the one who did not get up, being carried off on a stretcher with his left leg in a brace  with a booking from referee Howard Webb to send him on his way. The memory of another Bolton player being taken off here in far more serious circumstances just 10 days ago earned him a ripple of applause from around the ground  but he certainly did not deserve it.

Bale was again the danger on 36 minutes ripping a snorter just wide. Next Scott Parker burst towards the six-yard box only to see his close-range effort kept out, too.

Then came the 41st minute, the time when Muamba suffered his cardiac arrest here in the first game.

This time it produced a Bale drive that curled just too much and flew past the post as Bolton fans began a chorus of "Fabrice Muamba" to mark the moment.

Tottenham were just as relentless after the break.

Rafael van der Vaart rattled the bar with a terrific free kick, then Adebayor, broke through the middle for a one-on-one but his low shot bounced off Bogdan's knee. This was getting silly.

And when Bogdan denied Adebayor for the umpteenth time, Spurs' boss Harry Redknapp was up on his feet shaking his head in disbelief.

He would have been hanging his head if Ivan Klasnic had put Bolton ahead on a rare attack soon afterwards.

So Redknapp sent on sub Jermain Defoe and what happened? A goal-bound left-footer was saved by Bogdan!

When the keeper pushed over Bale's header, Spurs die-hards must have been fearing a replay. But Nelsen and Bale finally changed all of that to leave the Lane rocking and heading for Wembley.

DREAM TEAM

STAR MAN  ADAM BOGDAN (BOLTON)

TOTTENHAM: Cudicini 7, Walker 7, Assou- Ekotto 6, King 6, Nelsen 7, Modric 7, Livermore 6, Parker 8 (Defoe 6), Bale 8, van der Vaart 8 (Rose 6), Adebayor 8 (Saha 6). Subs not used: Friedel, Kaboul, Dos Santos, Kranjcar.

BOLTON: Bogdan 9, Ricketts 6, Alonso 7, Knight 7, Boyata 6 (K Davies 5), Eagles 7, M Davies 6, Reo-Coker-6, Pratley 4 (Ream 5), Miyaichi 6 Klasnic 6. Subs not used: Jaaskelainen, Sanli, Petrov, Ngog, Vela. Booked: Pratley.

REF: H Webb 7

pages.subdeck: HITTING THE SALES ... Arsene Wenger will spend early
pages.headline: Wenger in a rush
pages.teaser: THE Arsenal boss made a mess of his 2011 dealings and went on a last-day spree
pages.articlebody:
ARSENE WENGER plans to rush through new transfers to avoid a repeat of last summer's deadline chaos.

The Arsenal boss made a mess of his 2011 dealings and had to sign Mikel Arteta, Andre Santos and Per Mertesacker on the transfer window's final day.

But Wenger is intending to snap up Cologne striker Lukas Podolski for £11million in the next 48 hours.

And he could also splash £10m on Ajax defender Jan Vertonghen, £6m on Montpellier forward Olivier Giroud and up to £17m on Rennes playmaker Yann M'Vila just weeks after the end of the season.

pages.subdeck: FLYING SWANS ... Neil Taylor feels he is at a special club
pages.headline: Swansea is special
pages.teaser: NEIL TAYLOR insists Swansea stars are going nowhere  because they are already at a special club.
pages.articlebody:
NEIL TAYLOR insists Swansea stars are going nowhere  because they are already at a special club.

A number of Swans players have been linked with exits after impressing in the club's debut Premier League season.

The passing style of Brendan Rodgers' side has captured the imagination of fans and pundits.

And left-back Taylor, who was a target for Newcastle, said: "We have done it together as a football club.

"Every player and manager knows what a special football club it is to be at, especially with the style of football we play.

"I don't think any of the players here would swap it for anything.

"In those terms, it is a football club that is growing.

"If it ends up being a top-10 football club, there are not many places you want to go that will be better than here.

"While things happen in the summer, as they always do, our players are doing really well here.

"Money and all those sorts of things can make you think it's great.

"But the feeling you get after a game having played as a team and the style we played, you can't replace that with anything.

"That is a big factor for players at this club."

pages.subdeck: DOUBLE TOPS ... Owen insists he can star for at least two more years
pages.headline: I'm Owen nowhere
pages.teaser: BUT the Man United striker has played just FOUR games for the champions this term
pages.articlebody:
MICHAEL OWEN insists he has at least two more years at the top  despite playing just FOUR games for Manchester United this season.

Owen, 32, sidelined since November with a thigh strain, said: "My body feels as though it can play and my mind wants to and I think I still have another two or three years left.

"Some players are struggling to get out of bed and complain about their knees or Achilles. I never get pains like that.

"It is probably strange to hear that because people know I am injured. But joint-wise, I feel great.

"I don't think I am going to be one of those players who is still playing at 37 or 38, though."

pages.subdeck: IN A FIX ... Roberto Di Matteo has big-game pile-up
pages.headline: FA snub RDM bid
pages.teaser: BOSSES last night ruled out bringing the game forward 36 hours to ease fixture pile-up
pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO DI MATTEO'S plea to play Chelsea's FA Cup semi-final on a Friday night has been snubbed.

FA chiefs last night ruled out bringing the game forward 36 hours to ease Blues' fixture pile-up.

A Wembley semi against Tottenham is set for Sunday April 15.

And if Chelsea overcome Benfica, their Champions League last-four tie would be just two days later.

But FA sources claim the Metropolitan Police are against holding a huge tie on a Friday evening when fans could spend all day boozing.

Liverpool asked not to play their Cup semi on the Sunday as it coincides with the 23rd anniversary of the Hillsborough disaster.

pages.subdeck: CAR DEMANDS ... Lewis Hamilton
pages.headline: Lewis fancies a quickie
pages.teaser: BRIT star will hurry along his McLaren mechanics ahead of Shanghai next month
pages.articlebody:
LEWIS HAMILTON will hurry along his McLaren mechanics to make sure he gets the quickest car in China next month.

The 27-year-old finished third in both of this season's races  despite starting in pole position.

And Hamilton, who won the Chinese Grand Prix in Shanghai last year, is determined to be top dog again.

He said: "In qualifying we are very quick but we need to be quicker in the race. I don't think we are quick enough.

"We will have some upgrades for the car, I hope. I will go and push the guys to see if we can get some upgrades to try and squeak ahead in the race."

Hamilton's team-mate, Jenson Button, who won in China in 2010, added: "We have won it for the past two years, so I'm looking forward to it."

image.caption: CAR DEMANDS ... Lewis Hamilton

pages.subdeck: FLOORED ... England batsman Jonathan Trott after colliding with wicketkeeper
pages.headline: Spun dry
pages.teaser: KAMIKAZE cock-up merchants failed on day two in Galle to put hosts in charge of Test
pages.articlebody:
THE kamikaze, cock-up merchants  known as England's batsmen against spin bowling  were up to their miserable tricks again.

Andrew Strauss and his side somehow conspired to be bowled out in just 46.4 overs on day two of the First Test.

It was at least as bad and shambolic as anything they managed during their 3-0 whitewash to Pakistan earlier this year.

Then, England could at least use the excuse that Saeed Ajmal is a magician with the ball.

But this time they were bundled out by orthodox left-armer Rangana Herath, who will never feature in a spinners' hall of fame.

Graeme Swann hauled England back into contention with four wickets before the close as the bowlers once more tried to make up for the failings of the batsmen.

Swann removed most of Sri Lanka's big guns  including first-innings centurion Mahela Jayawardene for just five.

But chasing anything above 250 in the fourth innings on a deteriorating pitch will be mighty tough.

Herath took six wickets and suckered England's batsmen into a woeful collection of poor shots and fatal misjudgments.

Six were out lbw and many of the wounds were self-inflicted because of their apparent paranoia about the Decision Review System.

In the UAE against Pakistan, England hardly played a shot. Now they went the other way with a reckless mixture of heaves and sweeps.

All this after seven of the squad arrived early in Sri Lanka  five days before the rest  in order to acclimatise and practise against spin.

Strauss and Stuart Broad picked the wrong balls to sweep, Matt Prior and Samit Patel were leg before on the back foot when they should have gone forward.

And Kevin Pietersen was bowled reaching for a drive from his first ball after lunch.

As for Jonathan Trott, he perished to one of the most bizarre  and frankly comical  Test dismissals imaginable.

He missed a full toss from Herath and was stumped by Prasanna Jayawardene. But that was only the half of it.

Trott's helmeted head collided with the Sri Lankan keeper's gloves and he collapsed as though felled by a Klitschko right hand. He wandered off, a little groggy and a lot embarrassed.

The lower-order shamed the specialist batsmen as the final four wickets added 101  after the first six put on 92. Broad was second-highest scorer, Swann fourth, James Anderson fifth and, praise be, Monty Panesar the sixth best.

Ian Bell made 52  one more than in the entire series against Pakistan  before falling to a fine delivery from Herath which pitched on middle stump and hit off.

Herath bowled well but he is essentially a spinner in the style that England have seen hundreds of times down the years in county cricket. The pitch offered some assistance but to be bowled out in a session and a half was nothing short of scandalous.

Bell said: "It was good to spend some time in the middle, get some rhythm and change a pair of gloves for the first time this winter!

"But our score is not going to lie. To make fewer than 200 is not good, especially with nothing in the pitch to scare batsmen.

"It's not a lack of effort as we are all trying to get better at playing spin. We're working hard, trying to get into good positions to use our feet. But it's a long-term goal and won't happen overnight.

"What's very disappointing is not to back up our bowlers again who have been outstanding for the fourth Test running this winter. We have let them down by not giving them more time to rest in this heat.

"With the DRS, we're more aware that we have to play with our bat rather than the pad. You have to hit more, you can't kick anything."

Things started badly for England when the opening over of day two by Anderson went for 16 runs  eight off the bat of No 10 Chanaka Welegedera and eight leg-byes.

Anderson's slower ball did for Welegedera and he collected his fifth wicket of the innings when Jayawardene was last man out for a superb 180 out of Sri Lanka's 318.

Alastair Cook fell for nought to an inswinger from Welegedera and then England hit self-destruct.

Mind you, Sri Lanka also made a poor fist of it in their second innings. Broad speared one through Tillakaratne Dilshan's defences and then Swann took the next four.

Larihu Thirimanne was bowled by a beauty, Mahela was held at slip, Kumar Sangakkara edged to gully and Thilan Samaraweera had a brain storm and gave Swann the charge and was stumped.

image.caption: FLOORED ... England batsman Jonathan Trott after colliding with wicketkeeper

pages.subdeck: REVENGE BID ... Brit cycling hero Victoria Pendleton
pages.headline: Vic: Push off, Anna
pages.teaser: BRITAIN'S Olympic cycling champion accuses her big Aussie rival of abusing rules
pages.articlebody:
VICTORIA PENDLETON last night accused Aussie rival Anna Meares of 'pushing the rules' in a bitter cheat row.

Olympic champion Pendleton warmed up for next week's World Track Championships in Melbourne by claiming that when she pipped Meares to gold in the women's individual sprint in Beijing in 2008 it was revenge for an incident two years earlier.

At the 2006 World Track keirin in Bordeaux, Meares cut the Brit off in the event which sees riders paced by a moped before a dash to the line.

The move cost Pendleton the best position for the sprint finish and she missed out on a final place.

She declared: "I was really annoyed. I was feeling really good about progressing through to the final. That move really kind of shocked me.

"She's someone who likes to push the rules and I definitely don't."

The pair will battle in the sprint, team sprint and keirin in Oz and again in London.

image.caption: REVENGE BID ... Brit cycling hero Victoria Pendleton

article.caption: Hoy eyes treble

pages.subdeck: PEAK-TIME RACING ... Chris Hoy believes he'll be at his best ar the right time
pages.headline: Hoy eyes treble
pages.teaser: BRITAIN'S hero cyclist feels he's peaking at the right time to defend his Beijing crowns
pages.articlebody:
CHRIS HOY insists he is still on course to to successfully defend all THREE of his Olympic titles at London 2012.

Hoy, who celebrated his 36th birthday last Friday, believes he is peaking at the right time having won the keirin and individual sprint at the London World Cup  the test event in the Velodrome for this summer's Games.

Next week Hoy will lock horns with his room-mate Jason Kenny at the World Track Championships in Melbourne as he bids for the sole berths now allocated in the individual sprint and keirin and one on the team sprint. Kenny is the reigning world champion in the sprint and next week's competition will carry the greatest weight for Olympic selection.

Hoy admits: "I would love to repeat my performances at Beijing in London but to be honest, for me I'm just going to go out there and do my best and just hope to win a gold medal.

"If I could win two or three that would be an amazing result but really my aim is to be Olympic champion in London and if I can repeat (what I did) in Beijing, then that's the dream scenario.

"But I don't think it's impossible and I think that I would only enter an event if I believed I could win it.

"I've done pretty well this year so far and if I can have another good performance (in Melbourne) then hopefully it will be enough for selection.

"You're never 100 percent confident, you just go in there and hope that your performances are enough but Jason's had a fantastic few years.

"Since Beijing, he has been there or thereabouts at almost all the championships. He is world champion just now, so technically it's me that's knocking on the door trying to beat him.

"He's a great guy, we're good friends, we're room mates here, we get on really well and obviously that changes when you get on the track."

Kenny, who shares the same birthday as Hoy but is 12 years his junior, was awarded the 2011 world sprint title in January after Frenchman Gregory Bauge was stripped of his title for a doping violation.

He was knocked out of the quarter-finals in a major shock at last month's London World Cup but has pledged to hit back hard at Melbourne.

Hoy's victories in the keirin, team and individual sprint at Beijing made him the first Briton to clinch three Olympic golds in a single Games since Henry Taylor 100 years before  earning him a knighthood.

A member of Britain's national team since 1996, is bidding for his fourth Olympics after taking a silver on debut in the team sprint at the Sydney 2000 Games.

But Hoy remains reluctant to retire and already has his eye on the 2014 Commonwealth Games in Glasgow where the track cycling will be held in a velodrome bearing his name.

He said: "I'm 36 now and you find yourself reflecting on all these previous years and trips. You're telling stories to younger guys and they kind of look at you with glazed expressions. Then you suddenly realise you're almost double the age of some of the younger lads on the team.

"But I still love it as much as I did 12, 16 years ago... I think the ideal swansong would be to have a successful Games in London and then to go onto the Commonwealth Games in Glasgow because I've never actually raced internationally in my home country in Scotland.

"So that would be the ideal swansong, the great dream, to do the Olympics and the Commonwealth Games."

image.caption: PEAK-TIME RACING ... Chris Hoy believes he'll be at his best ar the right time

article.caption: Vic: Push off, Anna
